John Stafford Northcote (1850-1920; WWW), vicar, St Andrew, Westminster, 1889-1916. Son of 1st earl of Iddlesleigh; early career in engineering; curate under Dean Farrar at St Margaret's Westminster, 1878-81; m. (1881) Farrar's daughter, Hilda.

Samuel Smith (1836-1906, ODNB), Liverpool merchant, philanthropist, and MP (L) Flintshire, 1886-1906; a presbyterian, he campaigned for a wide range of mostly nonconformist causes, including anti-ritualism and disestablishment.
[Arthur] Ernest Guinness (1876-1949; WWW), engineer and director of Guinness, the brewing company.
Francis Denman (priest, 1888; CCD), sec., London Society for Promoting Christianity among the Jews, 1900-14. Christ Church Coll., Cambridge.
William Lefroy (1836-1909; ODNB), dean of Norwich, 1889-1909; Trinity Coll., Dublin; an evangelical, and a freemason; chaplain to the Grand Lodge of England, 1899-1900.

James Parker Smith (1854-1929; WWW), MP (LU), Partick, Lanarkshire, 1890-1906; private secretary to Joseph Chamberlain, when colonial secretary, 1900-3; director, Union Bank of Scotland; warden, Winchester College, 1915-20; m. (1882) Mary Lousia Hamilton; Ella's cousin.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Harry Reichel (1872-1931; ODNB), first principal of the University College of North Wales, Bangor, 1884-1927. Balliol Coll., Oxford; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1880-94; member, consultative committee, Board of Education, 1907-15; anglican and 'staunch Conservative' (ODNB).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Frederick Macmillan (1851-1936; ODNB), chairman, Macmillan & Co., 1896-1936. President, Publishers' Association, 1900, 1901, 1911, 1912; initiator of the 'net book' agreement, 1899; Kt, 1906.
Frederick Platt-Higgins (1840-1910; WWW), MP (C) Salford, 1895-1906.
Gilbert Murray (1866-1957; ODNB), regius professor of Greek, Oxford, 1908-36. St John's Coll., Oxford; member, League of Nations' committee of intellectual co-operation, 1922, and chairman, 1928.
Henry Alford (d. 1921; WWW), rector of Worthen, Shrewsbury, 1902-21; New Coll., Oxford.
Alfred Poynder (priest, 1889; CCD), vicar, St Michael, Burleigh St, London, 1894-1902; rector, Whitechapel, 1902.
Charles Craig (1869-1960; WWW), MP (C) South Antrim, 1903-22, Co. Antrim 1922-9; Capt., 11th Royal Irish Rifles, Ulster div., 1914-18.

[Henry] Russell Wakefield (1854-1933; WWW), rector, St Mary's, Bryanston Square, 1894-1909; mayor, Marylebone, 1903-5; prebendary, St Paul's, 1908-9; dean of Norwich, 1909-11; bishop of Birmingham, 1911-24; president, Free and Open Church, National Council of Public Morals, and Christian Counter Communist Crusade.
Robert Moberly (1845-1903; ODNB), regius professor of pastoral theology, 1892-1903, and canon of Christ Church Coll., Oxford. New Coll., Oxford.
James Simpson (1865-1948; WWW), principal, Leeds Clergy School, 1900-10. Trinity Coll., Oxford; canon of Manchester, 1910-11; canon, St Paul's Cathedral, 1911-28; dean of Peterborough, 1928-42.
Charles Davis (priest, 1847; CCD), rector of Littleton-Drew, Wiltshire, 1875. Wadham Coll., Oxford.
George Brett, sec., London diocese council for preventive, rescue and penitentiary work, 1899-1905.

Ralph Inge (1860-1954; ODNB), modernist churchman and prolific writer. King's Coll., Cambridge; fellow and tutor in Classics, Hertford College, Oxford, 1889-1904; vicar, All Saints', Ennismore Gardens, 1905-7; Lady Margaret professor of divinity, 1907-11; dean of St Paul's, 1911-34; columnist, Evening Standard and Morning Chronicle; eugenicist and pacifist; persuaded by Henson to forsake academic for ecclesiastical life and introduced Henson to liberal theology; dubbed 'The Gloomy Dean', following expression of doubts about human progress in The Church and the Age (1912); other publications include Truth and Falsehood in Religion (1906); Outspoken Essays (2 series, 1919, 1922); England (1926); Lay Thoughts of a Dean (1927).

William Hay Aitken (1841-1927; WWW), liberal evangelical and prolific author. Wadham Coll., Oxford; general superintendent, Church Parochial Mission Society, 1875-27; canon residentiary, Norwich Cathedral, 1900-27.
William Manning (priest, 1890; CCD), curate, St Stephen's, Westminster, 1889-1928. King's Coll., London.

John Masterman (1867-1933; WWW), professor of history, Univ. of Birmingham, 1902-9. St John's Coll., Cambridge; vicar, canon, sub-dean, St Michael's, Coventry, 1907-12; rector, St Mary-le-bow, Cheapside, 1912-22; suffragan bishop of Plymouth, 1922-33; brother of the Liberal MP and journalist C.F.G. Masterman.
Thomas Papillon (1841-1926; WWW), vicar of Writtle, Essex, 1884-1909. Balliol Coll. Oxford; hon. canon, St Alban's Cathedral, 1907-26.

James Wilson (1836-1931; ODNB), headmaster turned liberal theologian. Hulsean lecturer, Cambridge, 1898; vicar, Rochdale, and archdeacon of Manchester, 1890-1905; lecturer in pastoral theology, Cambridge, 1902-3; canon, Worcester, 1905-26.
Henry Knight (1859-1920; WWW), principal, Clergy Training School, 1901-11; bishop of Gibraltar, 1911-20.
Reginald Lightfoot (1836-1906; WWW), archdeacon, Oakham, 1880-1905. Balliol Coll., Oxford.

Title: Miss
Narrative: Possibly one of the seven daughters of Charles Thomson Ritchie, 1st Baron Ritchie of Dundee.
Hubert Handley (priest, 1886; CCD), vicar, St Thomas, Camden Town, 1894-1914. Lincoln Coll., Oxford.
William Brooke (priest, 1892; CCD), curate, East Ham, dio. St Alban's, 1895-1909. Wadham Coll., Oxford.
Arthur Atkinson (priest, 1890; CCD), rector, Greensted, Essex, 1898-1925. Oriel Coll., Oxford; editor, Christian Conference Essays (1900).
Edmund Sedgwick (priest, 1881), vicar, Fobbing, Romford, dio. St Alban's, 1902-7. St Edmund's Hall, Oxford.
Emmeline Knight [née Nicol] (1870-1953), youngest daughter of Robert Nicol, MD, London; m. (1904) Samuel Kirshbaum Knight.
George Trollope (1845-1929; ODNB), colonel in the Queen's Westminster Rifles, a militia unit, since 1891; speculative builder.
William Mann Trollope (1824-1915), solicitor; town clerk of Westminster, 1859-1901.
Richard Blackmore (b. 1860; CCD), headmaster, Westminster Abbey Choir School, 1898. Priest, 1886; Hertford Coll., Oxford.
William Rutherford (1853-1907; WWW), headmaster, Westminster School, 1883-1901; Henson's neighbour, living at 19 Dean's Yard; St Andrew's and Balliol Coll., Oxford; fellow, University Coll., Oxford.

Emma Hensley Long [née Henson] (1829-1912), Henson's aunt, younger sister of his father, Thomas; m. (1864) Samuel Long. Henson's second forename, Hensley, was bestowed in her honour; maintained close relationship with Henson throughout her life; paid Henson's fees on his appointment to St Margaret's, Westminster: Journal, 22 Jan. 1912.
Robert de Courcy Laffan (1853-1927; WWW), headmaster, 1884-99; rector, St Stephen Walbrook, 1899-1927; member, international and British Olympic committees 1899-27.
Philip Fyson (1846-1928; WWW), bishop of Hokkaido in Japan, 1896-1908; vicar, Elmley Lovett, 1908-25.
Augustus Wirgman (1846-1917; WWW), canon, Grahamstown cathedral, 1899-1917, and acting chaplain to the forces, South Africa, 1899-1900.
Sydney Gibbs (1887-1958), young parishioner at St Margaret's, Westminster; member of Henson's 'Guild of Perseverance'; prepared for confirmation by Henson in January 1903.
William Chart (1887-1945), young parishioner of Henson's while he was at St Margaret's, Westminster; member of Henson's 'Guild of Perserverance' and 'Guild of the Chancel'.
George Rudge (b. 1886), young parishioner at St Margaret's. Butcher's son working for his father, 1901; prepared for confirmation by Henson; commercial traveller, 1911.

William Ayerst (1830-1904; ODNB, WWW, Times), missionary career, then founding principal, Ayerst Hall, Cambridge, 1884-97 (and a member of the National Club, in Henson's parish); m. 1st, Ellen Drawbridge (d. 1901); m. 2nd, Anne Young (1842-1922).
Rolfe Scott-James (1878-1959; WWW), literary editor of The Daily News, 1906-12. Brasenose Coll., Oxford; member, executive of the Balkan Committee, 1903-14.
John Sheepshanks (1834-1912; ODNB), bishop of Norwich, 1893-1909. Christ's Coll., Cambridge; high churchman who was critical of extreme forms of ritualism.

Richard Knowling (1851-1919; WWW), professor of New Testament exegesis, King's Coll., London, 1894-1905. Balliol Coll., Oxford; Boyle lecturer, 1903-5; professor of Divinity and canon, Durham, 1905-19.

John Hutchison (b. 1859), Congregational minister at St Ives, Huntingdonshire, 1896-1903; ordained in the Church of England by Bishop Ridding of Southwell (Derbyshire Times, 28 Nov. 1903, 5); curate, St Mary's and All Saints' Chesterfield, 1904.

John Percival (1834-1918; ODNB), broad churchman and Henson's predecessor at Hereford. Queen's Coll., Oxford; headmaster of Rugby, 1887-95; strong supporter of the Workers' Educational Association, founded 1903; bishop of Hereford, 1895-1918.

George Ridding (1828-1904; ODNB), 1st bishop of Southwell, 1884-1904; advocate of liberty of thought and teaching in pursuit of truth; supported reunion of the protestant churches, while upholding the national church and the foundations on which it was built.
Francis Chavasse (1846-1928; ODNB), bishop of Liverpool, 1900-23. Corpus Christi Coll., Oxford; founder, Liverpool Cathedral; evangelical and dedicated pastoral bishop.

William Maclagan (1826-1910; ODNB), archbishop of York, 1891-1909. Peterhouse Coll., Cambridge; joint author with Frederick Temple, archbishop of Canterbury, of the Lambeth judgment, 1901, which curbed ritualist practices within the Church.
Henry Freeman (b. 1886), member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'; bioscope operator, 1911.
Frederick Brice (b. 1888), member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'; electrician, 1911.
Robert Stephens (1887-1957), member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'.
Charles Allen, member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'.
Philip Brind (1889-1960), member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'; clerk typist, 1911.
William White (b. 1888), member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'; Henson intervened when White became the victim of grooming attempts by Archibald Routledge.
Frederick Tisdall (1887-1968), member of 'Guild of the Chancel', prepared for confirmation by Henson in 1903; fruit salesman's clerk, Covent Garden, 1911.

John Battersby Harford (1857-1937; WWW), principal, Ripon College, 1902-12; canon, Ripon, 1911-37. Editor of the letters and poems of Handley Moule, Henson's predecessor as bishop of Durham, and author of Moule's life.

Charles Sherwood (d. 1947; WWW), assistant master, Westminster School, 1901-6, and curate, St Margaret's, Westminster, 1903-6. Magdalen Coll., Oxford; headmaster, St Lawrence Coll., Ramsgate, 1906-18, Ipswich School, 1919-33; warden, S. Andrew's Training House for Ordinands, Whittlesford, 1933-46.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Frances Balfour [née Campbell] (1858-1931; ODNB), sister-in-law of Arthur Balfour, prime minister; writer and suffragist; committed churchwoman in the Church of Scotland, with a London house; friend of Henson while at Westminster: Retrospect, I, 75; president, London Society for Women's Suffrage, 1896-1919; executive member, National Union for Women's Suffrage, 1897-1918.

Title: Sir
Narrative: [William] Robertson Nicoll (1851-1923; ODNB), influential nonconformist journalist. Univ. of Aberdeen; minister, Free Church of Scotland, 1874-85; founding editor of The Expositor, 1885-1923, the monthly literary review, The Bookman, 1889-23, and most notably The British Weekly, 1886-1923; described as 'the intellectual leader of nonconformity - the chief exponent of its thought, and the most effective advocate of its cause in the press' (ODNB).

Mark Pattison (1813-84; ODNB), classical scholar and fellow, Lincoln Coll., Oxford, 1861-84. Oriel Coll., Oxford; moved away from the tractarianism of his youth, embracing the scholarly vocation instead, particularly evident in his Isaac Casaubon (1875); published Memoirs (1885).

Thomas Carlyle (1795-1881; ODNB), writer, biographer, and historian. Critic of modern democracy; in Latter day pamphlets (1850), he referred to the 'twenty-seven millions mostly fools' whom Parliament addressed (no. 6); born in Ecclefechan in Annandale; moved to the house his wife had inherited from her father - Craigenputtoch farm, Dumfrieshire - from Edinburgh in 1828, shortly after his marriage.
Charles Beeby (1853-1942; CCD), vicar, Yardley Wood, 1887-1903. St Edmund's Hall, Oxford. The 'Beeby Case' erupted following his denial of the virgin birth in the pages of the Hibbert Journal.
John Perowne (1823-1904; ODNB), bishop of Worcester, 1891-1901. Corpus Christi Coll., Cambridge; evangelical with strong broad church leanings.
John Hunter (1849-1917; WWW), congregationalist minister. Mansfield Coll., Oxford; minister, King's Weigh House Church, Grosvenor Square, London, 1901-4; Trinity Church, Glasgow, 1904-13.
Irene Meiklejohn (1889-1968), m. (1910) Raymond Cheadle, son of canon John Cheadle.
Joseph Powell Williams (1840-1904; WWW), MP (LU) South Birmingham, 1885-1904; financial secretary to the war office, 1895-1900; suffered a seizure in the house of commons.

Alwyn Parker (1877-1951; WWW), diplomat and banker. Various posts at the Foreign Office, 1900-1919; a director of Lloyds Bank, 1919-1948; son of Alfred Traill Parker and Harriet Tinne (Fairlie, Ayrshire); m. (1908) Sophia Brodie; distant relation to Ella.
Winifred Parker (b. 1879), daughter of Alfred Traill Parker and Harriet Tinne (Fairlie, Ayrshire); m. (1909) Alfred Chevallier Parker, nephew of Lord Kitchener; distant relation to Ella.
George Putnam (1844-1930), president of G.P. Putnam's Sons, 1872-1924.

Arthur Stanley (1815-1881; ODNB), dean of Westminster Abbey, 1864-81. Balliol Coll. Oxford; campaigned for the exclusion of the damnatory clauses of the Athanasian Creed, as did Henson, who shared Stanley's vision of a comprehensive church.

Archibald Tait (1811-82; ODNB), archbishop of Canterbury, 1869-82. Balliol Coll., Oxford; broad churchman, critical of liberal theology and ritualism; architect of the Public Worship Regulation Act, 1874.

Samuel Wilberforce (1805-73; ODNB), bishop of Oxford, 1845-69, and Winchester, 1869-73. Oriel Coll., Oxford; prominent critic of liberal theology; high churchman though with limited sympathy for Tractarianism.

Arthur James Balfour (1848-1930; ODNB), Unionist prime minister, 1902-5, party leader 1902-11. A philosopher and theist; cousin of the Cecils; first introduced to Henson by Frances Balfour (Retrospect, I, 75); foreign secretary, 1916-19, and author of the 'Balfour declaration', 1917; lord president of the council, 1919-22, 1925-29; 1st earl of Balfour (1922).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Henry Campbell-Bannerman (1836-1908; ODNB), Liberal party leader, 1899-1908; prime minister, 1905-8.

Alfred Chevallier Parker (1875-1935; WWW), son of Harry Rainy Parker and Frances Kitchener (sister of Lord Kitchener). Lt Col (ret. 1909); Egyptian government service, 1909-1925; [British] governor of the Sinai peninsula, 1915-1923 (diaries, as 'Parker Pasha', published 1983); m. (1909) cousin, Winifred Parker; distant relation to Ella.
Edmund Wigram (priest, 1890; CCD), CMS missionary and principal, St John's divinity school, Lahore, 1896-1907.
Joseph Hall (1574-1656; ODNB), bishop of Exeter, 1627-41; bishop of Norwich, 1641-46.
Charles Clarke (priest, 1884; CCD), principal, Noble Coll., Masulipatam, 1886-1901, 1902-4. Emmanuel Coll., Cambridge.
Albert Parkhouse (1889-1916), a member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'; Killed in First World War.
Ernest Fontaine (b. 1889), a member of Henson's 'Guild of the Chancel'.
Arnold Oxford (priest, 1878; CCD), incumbent, St Philip's, Regent Street, 1899-1904. Christ Church Coll., Oxford; left the Church in 1904 and qualified as a doctor.

Robert Drane (1833-1914), antiquary and natural historian; pharmacist by profession, with premises on Queen St., Cardiff; founder of Cardiff Naturalists' Society, 1867; instrumental in the development of the National Museum of Wales.

George Margoliouth (1853-1924; WWW), editor, translator and commentator on ancient religious texts. Born in Poland to Jewish parents, converted to Christianity, ord. 1881 and took British citizenship in 1887; head of Hebrew, Syriac and Ethiopian manuscripts, British Museum, 1891-1914.

Frederic Chase (1853-1925; ODNB), Norrisian professor of divinity, Cambridge, 1901-5; president, Queens Coll., Cambridge, 1901-6; vice-chancellor, University of Cambridge, 1902-4; bishop of Ely, 1905-24; had a large part in revision of the Book of Common Prayer.
Charles Henry Robarts (1840-1904), barr. and fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1864; sub-warden, 1878-99 (resigned fellowship on marriage).
Henry Baylis (1817-1908; WWW), judge, Liverpool court of passage, 1876-1903; treasurer, Inner Temple, 1899-1908.

Alfred Lyttelton (1857-1913; ODNB), MP (LU) Leamington, 1895-1906, and (U) St George's, Hanover Sq., London, 1906-13; colonial secretary, 1903-5, responsible for introducing indentured Chinese labour in southern Africa; churchman, and opponent of Welsh church disestablishment.

Cyril Alington (1872-1955; ODNB), assistant master, Eton, 1899-1908. Trinity Coll., Oxford; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1896; headmaster, Shrewsbury, 1908-1916; headmaster, Eton, 1916-33; dean of Durham, 1933-1951; close friend of both Gore and Henson, of whom he wrote perceptively in A dean's apology: a semi-religious autobiography (1952).
Gertrude Gow [née Everett Green] (1855-1942), daughter of George Pycock Green and Mary Ann Everett Wood; m. (1885) James Gow.

Alexander Murray Smith (1866-1939), partner in Smith, Elder publishing firm; m. Emily Tennyson Bradley (1862-1946), daughter of George Bradley, dean of Westminster, and godchild of Alfred Tennyson; author of a number of works on Westminster Abbey.
Julia Robarts [née Eyre] (c. 1850), m. (1899) Charles Robarts.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Constance Manners [née Hamlyn-Fane] (1861-1920), m. John, 3rd Baron Manners (1852-1927).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Arthur Hardinge (1859-1933; ODNB), diplomat. Balliol Coll., Oxford; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1881; minister to Tehran, 1900-5, to Belgium, 1906-11, and to Portugal, 1911-13; ambassador to Spain, 1913-19.
George Dibblee (1868-1952; WWW), manager, Manchester Guardian, 1892-1912, and Field and Queen, 1913-19. Balliol Coll., Oxford; fellow and bursar, All Souls Coll., 1920-4.

William Chillingworth (1602-44; ODNB), anglican divine who had for a time converted to Roman catholicism before being reconverted by the influence of his godfather, William Laud; hesitant over subscription to the Thirty-Nine Articles; his Religion of Protestants: a safe way to salvation (1638) - including its assertion that 'the Bible is the religion of Protestants' - was used by Henson to support a view of the wide interpretative latitude of the Bible, over which the Church enjoyed no special authority: Henson, The Liberty of Prophesying (London, 1909), 40, 93-6.

Arthur [Cayley] Headlam (1862-1947; ODNB), theologian. New Coll., Oxford; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1885-97, 1924-47; rector of Welwyn, 1898-1901; editor, Church Quarterly Review, 1901-21; principal, King's College, London, 1903-13; regius professor of theology, Oxford, 1918-23; bishop of Gloucester, 1923-45; controversial chairman of the Church's Council on Foreign Relations, 1933-45; shared Henson's ecumenism and individualism, though not his opposition to Nazism; on his death, Henson wrote of him as 'my oldest clerical friend': Braley, Letters, 193-4.
Evelyn Headlam [née Wingfield] (1857-1924), m. (1900) Arthur Cayley Headlam, Henson served as witness at their wedding: Journal, 6 July 1900.
Gilbert Simpson, Henson's godson; m. (1918) Alice Berwick; remained close with Henson throughout his life; Henson regarded him more as a son then godson: Journal, 2 Apr. 1918.

James Dennistoun (1871-1939), Ella's brother, only son of James Dennistoun and Caroline Gore Booth. Military career, 1892-1919, retiring as Lt Col, Royal Artillery; m. (1910) Clara Morgan, daughter of Major-General Henry Morgan, Indian Army.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Catherine Wingate [née Rundle], (1858-1946).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Reginald Wingate (1861-1953; ODNB), governor-general, Sudan, and sirdar, Egyptian army, 1899-1916; high commissioner, Egypt, 1917-19; 1st baronet of Dunbar and Port Sudan (1920).

Title: Admiral
Narrative: Ernest Neville-Rolfe (1847-1909), admiral, Royal Navy (1907). Appointed rector's churchwarden at St Margaret's by Henson, serving from 1904 until his death; 'a good man, & a sincere & humble Christian whose friendship was worth having', Henson to Frances Balfour, 9 June 1909, NLS, Lady Frances Balfour MS, GD433/2/338.

Hanmer William Webb-Peploe (1837-1923; ODNB), vicar, St Paul's, Onslow Square, London, 1876-1919, and prebendary, St Paul's Cathedral, 1893-23. A leading evangelical and anti-ritualist; founder of the National Protestant Church Union, 1893, and active in the Evangelical Alliance, Keswick Convention and other evangelical bodies.

John Micklethwaite (1843-1906; ODNB), ecclesiastical architect, surveyor of the fabric of Westminster Abbey, 1898-1906, and architect to St George's Chapel, Windsor, 1900-6; founder member, Alcuin Club, 1897; carried out restoration of south transept and west front of the Abbey in consultation with William Douglas Caröe.

Archibald Fleming (1863-1941; WWW), highly successful minister of the Church of Scotland church of St Columba's, Pont St, 1902-41, attended by many prominent Scots resident in London. Edinburgh University; minister of Tron, Edinburgh, 1897-1902, and remained influential within the Church in Scotland; writer of much religious journalism, and became a successful broadcaster.

George Saintsbury (1845-1933; ODNB), regius professor of rhetoric and English literature, University of Edinburgh, 1895-1915. Prolific Tory journalist and literary reviewer, associated like Henson with The Saturday Review; m. Emily Fenn King.

Eustace Balfour (1854-1911; WWW), youngest brother of Arthur Balfour, prime minister; m. (1879) Frances Balfour; lt. col., London Scottish Volunteers, 1894-1903; partner, Balfour and Turner architects.
Edith Bruce [née Parker] (1868-1912), daughter of Samuel Sandbach Parker and Mary Isabella Gore-Booth. Ella's maternal first cousin; m. (1897) Charles Thomas Bruce.

Georgiana [Geordie] Gore [née Gore-Booth], (1873-1954), daughter of James Gore-Booth and Louisa Charlotte Trench. Ella's maternal first cousin; m. (1898) Frederick St. John Gore, Ella served as bridesmaid at their wedding.
Robert Kennett (1864-1932; ODNB), regius professor of Hebrew, Cambridge, and canon, Ely, 1903-32.
Amy Burkitt [née Parry] (1862-1948), daughter of William Parry, rector of Fitz, Shropshire; m. (1888) Francis Crawford Burkitt.

Francis Crawford Burkitt (1864-1935; ODNB), biblical scholar and theological modernist. Trinity Coll., Cambridge; Norrisian professor of divinity, 1905-35; publications include 'Texts and Versions' in Encyclopaedia biblica (1903), two-volume edition of the old Syriac gospels (1904), and Jewish and Christian apocalypses (1914); sometime vice-president of the Churchmen's Union.
Henry Jackson (1839-21; ODNB), regius professor of Greek, University of Cambridge, 1906-21, and fellow, Trinity Coll., Cambridge.
Edward Butler [in religion Dom Cuthbert] (1858-1934; ODNB), superior, Benet House, Cambridge, 1896-1904; abbot, Downside, 1906-22.

Title: Father
Narrative: William Sutcliffe (1856-1944; WWW), Roman catholic priest, 1888; head of St Edmund's House, Cambridge, 1897-1904; chief diocesan inspector, catholic diocese of Westminster 1906; canon, Westminster cathedral, 1909.

Title: Father
Narrative: Edmond Nolan (1857-1931; WWW), Roman catholic priest, 1882; master, St Edmund House, Cambridge, 1904-9; canon, Westminster cathedral, 1921.

Title: Father
Narrative: Arthur Barnes (1861-1936; WWW), Henson's predecessor as chaplain of the hospital of St Mary and St Thomas, Ilford, 1893-5. Received into the Roman catholic church, 1895; Trinity Coll., Cambridge, 1904; catholic chaplain, University of Cambridge, 1902-16, and University of Oxford, 1918-26; private chamberlain to popes Pius X and Benedict XV, 1904-17.
Oba Gbadebo I (1854-1920), Alake of Abeokuta [king of Egba, a Nigerian clan] from 1898; with Ladapo Samuel Ademola, his successor, he was received by Edward VII during their visit to Britain in 1904.

Donald Macleod (d. 1915; WWW), editor, Good Words, 1872-1905, a monthly journal with an evangelical slant, published in Edinburgh. Minister, The Park Church, Glasgow, 1869-1909; moderator, general assembly of the Church of Scotland, 1895-6; a chaplain to the king in Scotland.

Title: Lord
Narrative: James [Gascoyne-Cecil] (1861-1947; ODNB), Lord Cranborne, 4th marquess of Salisbury (1903), Conservative politician and leading lay churchman. University Coll., Oxford; lord privy seal, 1903-5; lord president of the council, 1922-4; lord privy seal, 1924-29, and leader, house of lords, 1925-9; active in the institutions and political defence of the Church of England, and in parliamentary management of the 1919 Enabling bill; member, Church Assembly's house of laymen, 1920-45; son of Henson's benefactor, the 3rd marquess, and elder brother of Lords William, Robert and Hugh Cecil. Henson commented in 1947 that 'my own career has been so much affected by contact with the House [of Cecil] that I feel almost a personal loss in the death of the last Marquis': Braley, Letters, 205.

Samuel Driver (1846-1914; ODNB), regius professor of Hebrew and canon, Christ Church, Oxford, 1883-1914. New Coll., Oxford; brought new critical standards to Old Testament studies, and sought to reconcile science and faith; publications include the Introduction to the literature of the Old Testament (1891; 9th edition, 1913).

James Dennistoun (1839-1908), Ella's father; only son of George Dennistoun and Margaret Wallis; Lieut, Royal Navy, 1854-1865; m. (1868) Caroline Gore Booth; very active within the Episcopal Church of Scotland.

Angela Georgina Burdett-Coutts (1814-1906; ODNB), philanthropist, after inheriting the fortune of her banker grandfather in 1837. Gave 3-4 million to charitable causes during her lifetime, including significant donations to the Church in London; m. (1881) William Ashmead Bartlett.

Edward Wood (1881-1959; ODNB), Conservative politican, and leading lay churchman. Son of Charles, 2nd viscount Halifax (1839-1934), inheriting his strong commitment to the Church, to anglo-catholicism and the English Church Union; Christ Church Coll., Oxford; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1903-10; author, John Keble (1909); MP (U), Ripon 1910-25; cabinet posts, 1922-4, 1924-5; 1st baron Irwin, 1925 and viceroy of India, 1926-31; cabinet posts, 1932-38; foreign secretary, 1938-40; ambassador, Washington, 1941-6; sometime member of house of laity, Church Assembly, and other religious bodies.
Arthur Bridge (priest, 1880, CCD), rector, All Saints, Worth, Crawley, 1896-1916.
Edward Caird (1835-1908; ODNB), idealist philosopher, and master, Balliol Coll., 1893-1907. The Evolution of religion (1893) were his Gifford lectures, 1891-2.

Henry Watkins (1844-1922; WWW), archdeacon and canon, Durham, 1882-1922. Balliol Coll., Oxford; Bampton lecturer, 1890; professor of Hebrew, University of Durham; examining chaplain to bishop of Durham.
William Rainsford (priest, 1874, CCD), rector, St George's, New York, 1882-1905. St John's Coll., Cambridge.

Ernest Rudling (b. 1891), pupil at Westminster City School and chorister (soloist) at St Margaret's. Henson asked his friend Violet Markham to help secure him a job in the Bank of England, but she was unsuccessful, largely, Henson suspected, because of a 'social standard' applied by the Bank: Henson to Markham, 24 Apr. 1910, Markham Papers.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Kenneth Muir Mackenzie (1845-1930; ODNB), baron Muir Mackenzie (1915). Balliol Coll., Oxford; permanent secretary to the lord chancellor, and clerk of the crown in chancery, 1880-1915; whip in house of lords for Labour governments, 1924, 1929-30; m. Amelia Margaret Graham (d. 1900), with whom he had three daughters.

Hubert Burge (1862-1925; ODNB), headmaster of Winchester, 1901-11; University Coll., Oxford; bishop of Southwark, 1911-19; bishop of Oxford, 1919-25; liberal in politics and the church; defended Henson's appointment to Hereford; first president of the Church's doctrinal commission, 1922 .

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Eldon Gorst (1835-1911; ODNB), MP (C) Cambridge University, 1892-1906 (Independent from 1903) vice-president of committee of council on education, 1895-1902, resigning when Balfour took charge of the Education bill; advocate of local authority control of schools; critic of Balfour's government for failing to take social reform seriously.

Beatrice Webb [née Potter] (1858-1943; ODNB), social reformer, fabian socialist and diarist. Served on many government committees, most prominently, the royal commission on the poor law, 1905-9, co-authoring its minority report; m. (1892) Sidney Webb, Lord Passfield; mentions Henson in her diary, 8 Feb. 1905, N. and J. Mackenzie (eds.), The Diary of Beatrice Webb, II (4 vols, 1982-5), 338, and 16 Apr., 1906, B. Webb, Our Partnership (1948), 340-1.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Dorothy Stanley [née Tennant] (1855-1926; WWW), painter and illustrator. Slade School of Fine Art; exhibited at Royal Academy, 1886.
Louis Mylne (1843-1921; WWW), bishop of Bombay, 1876-97; vicar, St Mary, Malborough 1897-1905 and prebendary, Salisbury cathedral, 1899-1905; rector, Alvechurch, 1905-17.

Title: Sir
Narrative: William Harcourt (1827-1904; ODNB), MP (L) West Monmouth 1895-1904; chancellor of the exchequer, 1886, 1892-5.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Oliver Lodge (1851-1940; ODNB), physicist. Principal of University of Birmingham, 1900-19; a spiritualist, and president, and Society for Psychical Research, 1901-4; in Raymond or Life and Death (1916) he recorded his experiences of trying to reach his son (killed in Flanders, 1915) through seances.
Austin Taylor (1858-1955; WWW), shipowner and MP (C) East Toxteth, Liverpool, 1902-10; chairman, Westminster Hospital, 1925-8.
Alice Hunt [née Elliott], m. (1895) Henry Arthur Hunt.

Harry Marks (1855-1916; WWW) founder proprietor of Financial News (1884-1916) and fraudster. Used his newspaper in 1887 to boost shares in a worthless gold company he owned in Transvaal; MP (C) Bethnal Green East, 1892-5, St, George Tower Hamlets, 1895-1900, Thanet, 1904-10.
John Illingworth (d. 1915; WWW), hon. canon, Christ Church, Oxford, 1905-15; author of Christian character: ... lectures on the elements of Christian ethics (1904).
Alfred Green, one of Henson's confirmation candidates at Ilford, whose confessions he heard: Journal, 20 Dec. 1898.

Alfred Caldecott (1850-1936; WWW), professor of Logic and Mental Philosophy, King's Coll., London, 1891-1917, and dean, 1913-17; prebendary, St Paul's Cathedral, 1915-35; rector of Great Oakley, 1917-25.
Henry Paget (1853-1937; WWW), vicar, St Pancras, 1887-1906. Christ Church Coll., Oxford; suffragan bishop of Ipswich, 1906-9, and Stepney, 1909-19; bishop of Chester, 1919-32.

John Ruskin (1819-1900; ODNB), the cultural commentator and art critic.Burial in Westminster Abbey was offered, but on his own wishes he was interred at Coniston, near his home; a memorial plaque to him was placed in the Abbey in Feb. 1902.

Title: Sir
Narrative: George Gabriel Stokes (1819-1903; ODNB), physicist and mathematician; Lucasian professor, Cambridge, 1849-1903; 'the best-known conservatively religious scientist of the late Victorian age'; Gifford lecturer, Edinburgh, 1890-2; he has a memorial plaque in the north aisle of Westminster Abbey.
Charles Ker (1860-1940; WWW), partner of McClelland, Ker & Co., chartered accountants.
Robert Bineham (1890-1930), young parishioner of Henson's while he was at St Margaret's; involved in Henson's 'Chancellors' and 'Shakespearians' groups; remained close with Henson into adulthood.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Henry Graham (1842-1930; WWW), chief clerk of the house of lords, 1888-1917.
Margaret Graham [née Compton] (1847-1931), daughter of William, 4th marquess of Northampton; m. (1884) Sir Henry Graham.

Edward Lloyd-Williams (1857-1931), active member of the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) over many years; served at Westminster and Royal dental hospitals, London; lieu-col. in the Volunteers: Times, 25 Feb. 1931, 16.

Ernest Pearce (1865-1930; ODNB), friend of Henson's from their time in Westminster (Retrospect, I, II), and admired for his historical work (Braley, Letters, 50-1); vicar, Christ Church, Newgate St., 1895-1911; ecclesiastical correspondent, The Times, from 1899; unofficial advisor to successive prime ministers on church appointments, and had a large part in the appointment of Henson to the bishopric of Hereford (see TNA, PREM5/7); canon, Westminster Abbey, 1911-19, treasurer, 1912-16, and sub-dean, 1918-19; assistant chaplain-general of the army, 1915-19; bishop of Worcester, 1919-30.
John Hacket (1592-1670; ODNB), bishop of Coventry and Lichfield, 1660-70. Biographer of his patron John Williams, dean of Westminster and archbishop of York, posthumously published in 1693.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Peile Thompson (1844-1918; WWW), bt.; curate, Christ Church Marylebone, 1881-5; Trinity Coll., Cambridge.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Henry Lawrence (1845-1908; WWW), barrister and JP; sub-treasurer, Inner Temple.

John Llewelyn Davies (1826-1916; WWW), vicar, Kirkby Lonsdale, 1889-1908. Trinity Coll., Cambridge; leading evangelical clergyman and almost the last surviving friend of F. D. Maurice; with D. J. Vaughan, translator of Plato's Republic: Times, 19 May, 1916, 11.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Courtenay Ilbert (1841-1924; ODNB), clerk of the House of Commons, 1902-21.
Charles Stubbs (1845-1912; WWW), dean of Ely, 1894-1906; Hulsean lecturer, 1904-5; bishop of Truro, 1906-12. Christian socialist, hymnist and poet.

William Douglas Carö e (1857-1938; ODNB), architect specialising in Arts and Crafts and gothic styles. Consulting architect to dioceses of Bath and Wells, Canterbury, Lichfield, Newcastle and to cathedrals of Canterbury, Durham, Southwell, St David's, Brecon, Jerusalem; carried out restoration of south transept and west front of Westminster Abbey in conjunction with John Micklethwaite.
Elinor Dicey [née Bonham-Carter], youngest daughter of John Bonham-Carter, MP for Portsmouth, 1830-1841.
Arthur Lionel Smith (1850-1924; ODNB), historian and master of Balliol Coll., Oxford, 1916-24; member, Archbishops' Committee on Church and State, 1913-16.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Frederick Barrington-Ward (1880-1938; WWW), fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1904-11; barrister.

Frederick Faber (1814-63; ODNB), anglican clergyman who became a Roman catholic priest in 1847 following Newman's conversion; poet and hymnist.
Rose Butcher [née Trench] (1848-1902), youngest daughter of Richard Chenevix Trench, archbishop of Dublin, 1863-84; m. Samuel Butcher.
Mary Prothero [née Butcher] (1854-1934), daughter of Samuel Butcher, bishop of Meath, 1866-76; m. (1882) George Walter Prothero.

Samuel Butcher (1850-1910; ODNB), eldest son of Samuel Butcher, bishop of Meath; professor of Greek, University of Edinburgh, 1882-1903; MP (U) Cambridge University, 1906-1910; much admired by Henson, with whom he made common cause over religious education during the controversy over the Liberal government's bill in 1906: Retrospect, I, 145.
Evelyn Murray [née Bruce], m. (1892) William Murray, of Murraythwaite.
William Walsh (1836-1918; WWW), archdeacon and canon, Canterbury, 1897-1918. Merton Coll., Oxford; suffragan bishop of Dover, 1898-1916.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Sidney Lee (1859-1926; ODNB), literary scholar and editor of Dictionary of National Biography, 1891-1917; publications included over 820 DNB articles, A life of Queen Victoria (1902) and King Edward VII: a biography (2 vols, 1925-7).

William Hunt (1842-1931; ODNB), historian and biographer whose works include History of the English Church, vol 1, the series which he edited with W. R. W. Stephens (9 vols, 1899-1910); major contributor to DNB.

William Stephens (1839-1902; ODNB), dean of Winchester, 1894-1902. Ecclesiastical historian whose works include the co-editorship with William Hunt of the first four volumes of History of the English Church (9 vols, 1899-1910).

Title: Lord
Narrative: John Strutt (1842-1919; ODNB), 3rd Baron Rayleigh; Cavendish professor of experimental physics, Cambridge, 1879-84; professor of natural philosophy, Royal Institution of Great Britain, 1887-1905; Nobel prize, 1904, for discovery of argon; his spiritual interests ranged across anglicanism and the Society for Psychical Research.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Evelyn Strutt [née Balfour] (d. 1934), sister of Arthur Balfour, prime minister.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Robert Hudson (1864-1927; ODNB), secretary of Liberal Central Association and National Liberal Federation 1893-1927; chairman, finance committee of British Red Cross and Order of St John, 1914-22; trustee, Westminster Abbey restoration appeal, 1920; m. (1st, 1889) Ada Hammerton, (2nd, 1923) Mary Harmsworth [née Milner], widow of Lord Northcliffe.
Thomas Wright (1851-1928), clerk of works, Westminster Abbey, 1871-1906. There is a memorial stone to him in the south cloister.
Alfred Tennyson (1809-1892; ODNB), 1st Baron Tennyson (1883), poet Laureate, 1850-92.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Elliott Lees (1860-1908; WWW), MP (C), Birkenhead, 1894-1906
John Ainsworth (1844-1923; WWW), MP (L) Argyllshire, 1903-18; baronet, 1916.
Ada Hudson [née Hammerton] (b. 1865), m. (1889) Robert Hudson.
Betty Manners (1889-1962), daughter of 3rd baron Manners; m. (1918) Arthur Asquith, son of H. H. Asquith.
Angela Manners (1889-1970), daughter of 3rd baron Manners; m. (1925) Christian Malise Hore-Ruthven.
Frances Maurice (1888-1958), daughter of General Sir John Frederick Maurice.

Frederick Maurice (1805-72; ODNB), Church of England theologian, influential for his incarnationalism, doubts about eternal punishment, and advocacy of a social mission; probably these, rather than his promotion of Christian socialism, explain Henson's reference to him as prophetic.

Title: Sir
Narrative: George Webbe Dasent (1817-96; ODNB), expert on Scandanavian literature and mythology.
William Fearon (1841-1924; WWW), headmaster, Winchester Coll., 1884-1901. Archdeacon of Winchester, 1903-20.

Wilson Carlile (1847-1942; ODNB), rector, St Mary-at-Hill, City of London, 1891-26; founded the Church Army in 1882, to undertake evangelistic work among the urban poor, in similar style to the Salvation Army.
Eustace Talbot (1873-1905), physician, St Bartholomew's hospital, London; son of John Gilbert Talbot, MP.
Colin Campbell (1859-1914), attorney-general, Manitoba, 1900-11.

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Dorington (1832-1911; WWW), MP (C) Tewkesbury, 1886-1906.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Melville Leslie Macnaghten (1853-1921; WWW), assistant commissioner and chief of the criminal investigation dept., Metropolitan Police, 1903-13.
Mary Steel-Maitland [née Ramsay-Gibson-Maitland] (1871-1944), daughter of Sir James Ramsay-Gibson-Maitland.

Hardinge Giffard (1823-1921; ODNB), 1st earl of Halsbury (1898), judge, law lord, and lord chancellor in Conservative and Unionist governments, 1885-6, 1886-92, 1895-1905. Merton Coll., Oxford; high steward, University of Oxford, from 1896; a leader of the 'die hard' and 'last ditch' opposition to the Parliament bill in 1910-11.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Clinton Dawkins (1859-1905; WWW), financial member, council of governor-general, India, 1899; partner in the bankers, J. S. Morgan and Co., 1900-1905.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Dyce Duckworth (1840-1928; ODNB), 1st bt (1909), physician, St Bartholomew's hospital, 1883-1905.

John Troutbeck (1848-1912, WWW), coroner for Westminster, 1888-1912, and south west London, 1902-12, courting controversy with the medical profession (obituary, Times, 1 Mar. 1912, 11); deputy high bailiff, Westminster, 1900-1912; son of Elizabeth Forbes Duckworth and John Troutbeck (1832-99), minor canon, Westminster Abbey; deep interest in church music and played viola in the orchestra at the coronation, 1911.
William McVickar (1843-1910), bishop of Rhode Island, 1898-1910.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Olga Montagu (d. 1951), daughter of Rear Admiral Victor Montagu.
Pearson McAdam Muir (1846-1924; WWW), minister of Glasgow Cathedral, 1896-1915.
Rosa Saxton (1889-1971), young parishioner of Henson's while attached to St Margaret's, Westminster; sister to Albert and Edwin; m. (1919) Daniel De Lough.

Title: Lord
Narrative: Henry Douglas-Scott-Montagu (1832-1905; WWW), 1st Baron Montagu of Beaulieu (1885).
Carl Gustav Adolf von Harnack (1851-1930), German Lutheran theologian. Publications include The expansion of Christianity in the first three centuries (2 vols, 1904-5).
John Marshall Lang (1834-1909; ODNB), Church of Scotland minister and principal of Aberdeen University, 1900-9. University of Glasgow; father of Cosmo Gordon Lang, archbishop of Canterbury, 1928-42.
John Diggle (1847-1920; WWW), rector, Birmingham, 1902-5, and rural dean, Birmingham, 1903-4; bishop of Carlisle, 1905-20.
Thomas Jex-Blake (1832-1915; ODNB), headmaster, Rugby School, 1874-87; dean of Wells, 1891-1911.
William Clark (1829-1912; WWW), professor of moral philosophy, Trinity Coll., Toronto, 1883-1908. Hertford Coll., Oxford; left the Congregationalist church for the Church of England.
Phinehas Hunt (priest, 1852; CCD), rector, St Kevin, Dublin, 1883-1910.
Samuel Young (1822-1918; WWW), Belfast businessman and MP (N), 1892-1918.
Francis Roxburgh (1850-1935; WWW), barr., Middle Temple, 1873; Trinity Hall, Cambridge.

Constance Flower [née Rothschild] (1843-1931; ODNB), m. (1877) Cyril Flower, who in 1892 became lord Battersea; a philanthropist, author, and journal-keeper; developed a strong interest in Christianity.
Reginald Adderley (1857-1934; WWW), brother of James Adderley; vicar, St Augustine, South Hackney, 1899-1905.

Marie Corelli [Mary Mackay] (1855-1924; ODNB), novelist. Her blending of Christian themes, mysticism and portraits of contemporary figures irritated many establishment figures and drew the ridicule of the literary elite, but the same notoriety ensured public popularity and high sales; she was supposed to have alluded to Henson in her novel God's good man (1904).
Charles Plummer (1859-1948; WWW), owner of Sunderland Hall, Galashiels, Selkirk; lord-lieutenant of Selkirk, 1919-48.

Title: St
Narrative: St Charles Borromeo (1538-84), archbishop of Milan, 1564-84. Leading figure in the counter-reformation, implementing the canons and decrees of the Council of Trent.
George Tavener Miller (1839-c.1917), businessman and member, Westminster school board, 1875.
Henry Erskine (1838-1921; WWW), sarjeant-at-arms, house of commons, 1885-1915.
Lucy Clifford [née Lane] (1846-1929; WWW), novelist, dramatist, and journalist; m. William Kingdom Clifford (d. 1879), mathematician and philosopher.

Louise Creighton [née von Glehn] (1850-1936; ODNB), leading churchwoman, social activist, and writer of popular biographies and histories; m. Mandell Creighton, bishop of London, 1897-1901; supported 'Life and Liberty' movement in the Church, and drew Henson's opprobrium as a result; member, Church Assembly, 1920-30.
William Reason, mayor of Finsbury, 1905-6.
William Hillier Onslow (1853-1911; ODNB), 4th Earl Onslow (1855), landowner and Conservative politician; president of the board of agriculture and fisheries 1903-5.
Arthur Coleridge (1830-1913), founder of the Bach Choir and great-nephew of the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge; funeral service held in St Margaret's, Westminster: Times, 30 Oct. 1913, 11.
Edward Reginald Frampton (1870-1923), painter who specialised in murals; also engaged in stained-glass work, a skill he learnt mostly from his father, Edward Frampton.

Aubrey Rees (1871-1945), founding secretary, National association of grocer's assistants; founder, National League of Young Liberals, 1903; author, The grocery trade: its history and romance (1923); active in the British Empire Film Institute in the interwar years.
Edward Sanderson (d. 1930, WWW), prebendary and canon of Chichester Cathedral, 1903-1930.

Henry Villiers (1837-1908; WWW), vicar, St Paul's Knightsbridge, 1881-1908, and prebendary, St Paul's Cathedral, 1895-1908. A 'pronounced...High Churchman', who in convocation acted as an unofficial spokesman for the English Church Union: Times, 10 Sept. 1908, 9.
Gwendolin Herbert [née Gorst] (d. 1932), hon. sister, order of St John of Jerusalem.
Edward Herbert (d. 1936; WWW), capt., Black Watch, 1894; retired as Brig.-Gen., 1920.

Samuel Barnett (1844-1913; ODNB), canon, Bristol, 1893-1906, and Westminster, 1906-13, sub-dean, 1913. Founder of Toynbee Hall (1884), a rival secular settlement to the religious Oxford House; a christian socialist, author with this wife Henrietta Barnett, of Practicable socialism: essays on social reform (1888); clashed with Henson at Westminster over procedural matters, fuelled by their opposed political and social views.

Henrietta Octavia Barnett [née Rowland] (1851-1936; ODNB), social reformer, strongly influenced by Octavia Hill, by whom she was introduced to Samuel Barnett (m. 1873). Influential in the development of the Women's University Settlement in Southwark (1887) and Hampstead Garden Suburb (1903). Prolific author on social issues as well as her husband's biographer.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Henry Irving [né Brodribb] (1838-1905; ODNB), actor and manager of the Lyceum theatre, 1878-1905; first actor to be knighted (1895).

Title: Lord
Narrative: George Hamilton (1845-1927; ODNB), MP (C), Ealing, 1885-1906. Secretary of state, India, 1895-1903; chairman, royal commission on the poor law, 1905-9.

Henry Montagu Butler (1833-1918; ODNB), master of Trinity Coll., Cambridge, 1886-1918. Trinity Coll., Cambridge; headmaster of Harrow, 1859-85; dean of Gloucester, 1885-6; a liberal in politics and churchmanship, and a much-admired preacher.

Title: Lord
Narrative: Victor Bulwer-Lytton (1876-1947; ODNB), 2nd earl of Lytton; a Conservative, but with liberal views; governor of Bengal, 1922-7, Viceroy and acting governor of India, 1925; vice-chairman of the League of Nations Union, 1935-8, and chairman, 1938-45.
Herminone Bulwer-Lytton (1905-2004), m. (1930) Cameron, 1st baron Cobbold.
[William] Bramwell Booth (1856-1929; ODNB), chief of staff, Salvation Army, 1881-1912, then succeeded his father, William Booth, as its general.
James Round (1842-1916; WWW), MP (C) Harwich, 1885-1906.

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Kennaway (1837-1919; ODNB), MP (C) Honiton, 1884-1910. Energetic evangelical churchman; president of the Church Missionary Society; member, Church Association, and house of laymen, Representative Church Council.
Philip Smith (1845-1929; WWW), barrister and layman, chancellor of several dioceses including Durham, 1903.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Frederick Milner (1849-1931; WWW), MP (C) Bassetlaw, 1890-1906.
Jesse Collings (1831-1920; ODNB), MP (LU) Bordesley, Birmingham, 1886-1918. Chamberlainite liberal and land reformer; under-secretary, home office, 1895-1902.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Frederick Halsey (1839-1927; WWW), 1st baronet (1920), MP (C) Watford, 1885-1906.
Edward Chapman (1839-1906; WWW), MP (C) Hyde, Cheshire, 1900-6.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Robert Mowbray (1850-1916; WWW), MP (C) Prestwich, 1886-95, and Brixton, 1900-6; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1873.
Harry Duff (1855-1905), barrister. Fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1878-90; one of the friends at All Souls with whom Henson had religious arguments: Journal, 5 Oct. 1885.
Henry Thomas (1864-1940; WWW), schoolteacher. Balliol Coll., Oxford; assistant master, Eton, 1887-1909; priest, 1893; headmaster, Lancing, 1909-25.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Thomas Holland (1835-1926; ODNB), Chichele professor of international law and diplomacy, 1874-1910, and fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1875-1926.
Hestor Alington [née Lyttelton] (d. 1958), youngest daughter of George, 4th lord Lyttelton and half-sister of Alfred Lyttelton.
Francis Warre-Cornish (1839-1916), historian and master at Eton, 1861, vice-provost, 1893-1916.

Title: Sir
Narrative: William Walrond (1849-1925; WWW), 1st Baron Waleran (1906). MP (C) Tiverton, 1885-1906; chief government whip, 1895-1902; chancellor, duchy of Lancaster, 1902-5.
William George Walrond (1906-66; WWW), 2nd Baron Waleran (1925).
Francis Aglionby (1848-1937), vicar, Christ Church, Westminster, 1882-1917.

James Lowther (1855-1949; ODNB), MP (C) Penrith 1886-1921, and speaker, House of Commons, 1905-21. Chaired speaker's conferences on electoral reform, 1916-17, and devolution, 1919; 1st Viscount Ullswater (1921); published A Speaker's Commentaries (2 vols., 1925). Henson dedicated a collection of his St Margaret's sermons, The Creed in the Pulpit (1912) to him, described as delivered in 'the Speaker's church'.
Percy Gates (d. 1940; WWW), businessman and mayor of Kensington, 1904.
Andrew Gow (1886-1978; ODNB), classical scholar. Trinity Coll., Cambridge.
Fanny Craik [née Duffield] (1849-1923), m. (1873) Henry Craik.
George Craik (1874-1929), chief constable, metropolitan police, 1910-14.
Leigh Nixon (1871-1941; WWW), deputy minor canon, Westminster, 1903-6; minor canon, Westminster, 1906-1933; precentor, Westminster, 1912-1933.
Alan Perkins (1897-1971), son of Joceyln H. T. Perkins; m. (1927) Doris Macdonald Speedy.
Michael Perkins (1898-1932), son of Joceyln H. T. Perkins; zoologist.
Donald Aiken-Sneath (1868-1922), minor canon, Westminster, 1902-22. Lincoln Coll., Oxford.
Ethel Sneath [née Bagott] (1872-1962), m. (1897) Donald Sneath, minor canon, Westminster.

Herbert Westlake (1875-1925; WWW), minor canon, Westminster, 1909-25; assistant keeper, Westminster Abbey records, 1918-25; author, New guide to Westminster Abbey (1916), Westminster (1919), Westminster Abbey (2 vols., 1923); m. (1913) Edith Raynor.
John Troutbeck (1894-1971), son of John Troutbeck, coroner, Westminster; m. (1924) Katherine Morley; British diplomat.
George Troutbeck (1891-1971), son of John Troutbeck, coroner, Westminster; m. (1925) Phyllis, daughter of Henry Beeching and Mary Plow; master, Westminster School, 1924-1951.

William Dams (1874-1968; CCD), assistant master, St Paul's Cathedral choir school, 1905-8; head of Westminster Abbey choir school, 1908-15; minor canon, Westminster Abbey, 1908-32; assistant master, Westminster School, 1916-32; lecturer in Theology, King's Coll. London, 1932-5.
Mary Beeching [née Plow] (1866-1952), eldest daughter of A. J. Plow; m. (1891) Henry Beeching.
Harriet Beeching (1891-1949), daughter of Henry Beeching and Mary Plow; m. (1917) Alyn Arthur Guest-Williams.
Phyllis Beeching (1894-1955), daughter of Henry Beeching and Mary Plow; m. (1925) George, son of John Troutbeck, coroner, Westminster.
Helen Beeching (1895-1983), daughter of Henry Beeching and Mary Plow; m. (1917) Edward Fanning.
George Nall (1860-1940), classical master, Westminster School, 1886-1922; author, The life of a sea trout (1930); m. (1909) Mary Howarth, journalist.
Samuel Day (1878-1950), assistant master, Westminster school, 1903-10; amateur sportsman.
George Radcliffe (1868-1947), chapter clerk, Westminster Abbey, 1900-17, and receiver-general, 1902-17; deputy high sheriff, Westminster, 1912-21.
Arthur Guy Sandars Raynor (1863-1935), assistant master, Westminster School, 1885-1921; Master of the King's scholars, 1886-1921; vicar, Steventon, 1921-4; rector, Warehorne, 1924-31.

Anatoly Stessel (1848-1915), commander of the major Russian military and naval base at Port Arthur in Manchuria during the Russo-Japanese war of 1904-5; after a prolonged siege, he surrendered the base to Japanese forces in January 1905.
Arthur Henson Rawle (1860-1942), Henson's paternal first cousin; son of Richard Rawle and Elizabeth Henson; m. (1882) Alma Strong; wool and hide merchant.
Marshall Field (1834-1906), founder of the Marshall Field department stores, based in Chicago; m. Delia Caton [née Spencer].
Henry Leighton Goudge (1866-1939; WWW), principal, Wells Theological Coll., 1895-1903. University Coll., Oxford; regius professor of divinity, 1923-39.
James Cuthbert Gow (1891-1929), drowned off Canada on Mauretania.
Roderick Gow (1893-1916), killed in First World War.
Louisa Montagu Douglas-Scott [née Hamilton] (1836-1912), duchess of Buccleuch and duchess of Queensbury.
Albert Grey (1851-1917; ODNB), 4th Earl Grey; Liberal unionist and imperialist: governor-general, Canada, 1904-11; president, Royal Colonial Institute, 1911-17.
William Booth (1829-1912; ODNB), founder, 1878, and first general of Salvation Army.

Narrative: Frederick Treves (1853-1923; ODNB), surgeon, London Hospital, 1884-1923, and to Queen Victoria, Edward VII and George V; famously operated on Edward VII, after postponement of the coronation in 1902, for which made a baronet.
Caroline Dennistoun [née Gore Booth] (1842-1905), Ella's mother; daughter of Henry Gore Booth and Isabella Smith; m. (1868) James Dennistoun.
Thomas Nichol (1846-1916; WWW), professor of divinity and biblical criticism, University of Aberdeen, 1899-1916.

Title: Lord
Narrative: Herbert Eaton (1848-1925; ODNB), 3rd Baron Cheylesmore (1902). Military officer and chairman, National Rifle Association, 1903-25.

Title: Sir
Narrative: James Baillie (1872-1940; ODNB), professor of moral philosophy, University of Aberdeen, 1902-24; vice-chancellor, University of Leeds, 1924-38.
William Davidson (1848-1929), professor of logic and metaphysics, University of Aberdeen, 1895-1926.
Henry Cowan (1844-1932; WWW), professor of church history, University of Aberdeen, 1889-1924.
William Curtis (1876-1961; WWW), professor of systematic theology, University of Aberdeen, 1903-15; professor of biblical criticism, University of Edinburgh, 1915-46.
William Elphinstone (1431-1514; ODNB), bishop of Aberdeen and founder of the University of Aberdeen.
Amelius Lockwood (1847-1928; ODNB), landowner and retired lieut-col., Coldstream Guards; MP (C), Epping, 1892-1917; 1st baron Lambourne (1917).

Title: Lord
Narrative: Alfred [Milner] (1854-1925; ODNB), Viscount Milner; high commissioner, South Africa, 1897-1905; member, imperial war cabinet, 1916-18; secretary for war, 1918; secretary of state, colonies, 1918-21.

Eloise Heathcote-Drummond-Willoughby [née Breese] (1882-1953).

Narrative: Gilbert [Heathcote-Drummond-Willoughby] (1830-1910), 1st earl of Ancaster; a hereditary joint (and acting) lord great chamberlain, 1888-1901.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Evelyn Gordon (1846-1921), m. (1863) Gilbert Heathcote-Drummond-Willoughby, the future 1st earl Ancaster.

Title: Princess
Narrative: Patricia of Connaught (1886-1974), second daughter of 1st duke and duchess of Connaught; m. (1919) Sir Alexander Ramsay.

Title: Duke of Connaught
Narrative: Arthur, Ist duke of Connaught (1850-1942; ODNB), 3rd son of Queen Victoria. Military career; field marshal, 1902; inspector-general of the forces 1904-7; commander-in-chief Malta, 1907-9; governor-general, Canada, 1911-16.

Narrative: Louise of Prussia (1860-1917), m. (1879) 1st duke of Connaught.
Whitelaw Reid (1837-1912), United States ambassador in London, 1905-12.
Francis Bain (1863-1940; ODNB), scholar and writer. Fellow of All Souls, Coll., Oxford, 1889-96; professor of history and political economy, Deccan Coll., Poona, India, 1892-1919.
John Burgon (1813-88; ODNB), dean of Chichester, 1876-88.
William [Will] Crooks (1852-1921; ODNB), MP (Lab) Woolwich, 1903-10, 1910-18; mayor of Poplar, 1901; devout Christian.
Kenneth Balfour (1863-1936; WWW), military officer and MP (C) Christchurch, Hants, 1900-6. Member, church assembly, 1925.
Hersey Butler (1889-1968), daughter of Sir Thomas Butler; m (1919) Ivo Twisleton-Wykeham-Fiennes, 20th baron Saye and Sele.
Emma Dennis [née Mumby] (1881-1957), housemaid to the Hensons, 1902-1906; m. (1906) Clement Dennis, with Henson officiating.
Clement Dennis (1874-1958), police constable (ret. 1924); Henson officiated at his marriage (1906) to Emma Mumby.

Charles Masterman (1873-1927; ODNB), politician, journalist and progressive social commentator.
