Alfred Ernest Parker (1880-1914), distant relation of Ella; son of Alfred Traill Parker and Harriet Tinne (Fairlie, Ayrshire); m. (1909) Joan Bowes-Lyon; military career, 1901-11, retiring as captain, Black Watch; resumed service, 1914, and killed in First World War.
Philip Waggett (1862-1939; ODNB), member of the Anglican religious order, St John the Evangelist, Cowley, 1892. Christ Church Coll., Oxford; army chaplain during WWI.
Walter Lawrence (1850-1941), bishop of Massachusetts, 1893-1927, in the Episcopal Church in the USA.
Henry Woods (1842-1915; WWW), master of the Temple, 1904-15. Corpus Christi Coll., Oxford.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Paul Vinogradoff (1854-1925; ODNB), jurist and historian. Corpus Christi professor of Jurisprudence, Oxford, 1903-25.
Harry Sharp (priest, 1882; CCD), vicar, St Hilda's, Leeds, 1889-1908.
Ernest Sandford (1839-1910; WWW), archdeacon of Exeter, 1888-1909. Christ Church Coll., Oxford.
George Miller (priest, 1866; CCD), vicar, Holy Trinity, Vauxhall Bridge Road, London, 1870-1910.
Henry Bevan (1854-1935; WWW), archdeacon of Middlesex, 1903-30.
Elizabeth Miller [née Tennant] (1846-1925), daughter of Rev. William Tennant, St John's, Westminster.
Charles Dundas (1847-1932; WWW), archdeacon of Dorset, 1902-7. Brasenose Coll., Oxford.
Algernon Ryder (priest, 1871; CCD), rector of Maresfield, dio. Chichester, 1902. St John's Coll., Cambridge; curate, St Margaret's, Westminster, 1873-6.

John Gott (1830-1906; ODNB), bishop of Truro, 1891-1906, and the senior clergyman in the Home Reunion Society; anglo-catholic and Conservative, though in Truro he knew the importance of good relations with nonconformists.
Henry Le Bas (priest, 1854; CCD), preacher at Charterhouse public school, 1871-1910; vicar, St Mary's, Bedfont, London, 1859-71.
John Ware (1863-1907; CCD), vicar, East Ham, 1893-1907, and rural dean, South Barking, 1900-7; English first-class cricketer.

Title: Sir
Narrative: [John] Frederick Maurice (1841-1912; ODNB), major-general, and commander of Woolwich army district, 1895-1902; m. Anne [Annie] Frances [née Fitzgerald]; influential writer on military subjects, who contributed to debates on 'national efficiency' and measures to improved the health of school-children; publications include the biography of his father, Life of Frederick Denison Maurice (1884).
Henry Bartram (1849-1934), vicar, St Mary Virgin, Dover, 1900-12; honorary canon of Canterbury, 1902.
Janet Neville-Rolfe [née Brand] (1846-1908), m. (1885) Ernest Neville-Rolfe.

Horatio [Nelson, né Bolton] (1823-1913; WWW), 3rd earl Nelson; energetic lay churchman with high-church inclinations; chairman, Home Reunion Society. Nelson criticised Henson's advocacy of inter-communion with non-episcopal churches as a hindrance to appropriate reunion of the British protestant churches (Times, 11 July 1902, 5); in reply, Henson's letter (Times, 14 July 1902, 12) argued that insistence on an unaltered episcopacy (the Society's approach) was the chief obstacle. Henson later included criticism of Nelson's book Home Reunion: reflections on the present position of nonconformists and an appeal for a better mutual understanding (1905) in a review article, 'The prospects of Christian reunion', Christian World, 16 Nov. 1905, 21.
Herbert Jones (1861-1920; WWW), rector of Petworth, 1897-1906. Trinity Coll., Cambridge.

William Bailward (1852-1914), social reformer. Balliol Coll., Oxford; hon. sec., Charity Organisation Society, Bethnal Green, 1887-1918; Guardian, Poor Law Union, Bethnal Green; author of The slippery slope: and other papers on social subjects (1920).
John Phillips, editor of the Yorkshire Post, 1903-19.
Florence Booth [née Soper] (1861-1957), m. (1882) Bramwell Booth; leader of women's social work in the Salvation Army.
Murdo Mackenzie (1836-1912), minister at Free North Church, Inverness, 1887-1912; moderator of the Free Church, 1907.

Charles Stuart Parker (1829-1910; ODNB), MP (L), Perthshire, 1868-74; Perth, 1879-92. University Coll., Oxford; involved in educational policy reform in both England and Scotland; lived at Fairlie House (Aryshire, Scotland), where the Hensons often visited; distant relation to Ella, affectionately referred to by Henson in his journals as 'Uncle Charles'.

Robert Gregory (1819-1911; ODNB), dean of St Paul's, 1891-1911, canon of St Paul's, 1868-91. Ritualist inspired to ordination by Tracts for the times; strong supporter of church schools, serving on London School Board, 1873-80; publications include History of elementary education (1895).
Edith Lloyd-Williams [née Hall] (1859-1939), m. (1885) Edward Lloyd-Williams.
Ellen Tomlinson (1838-1919), St Margaret's, Westminster parishioner.
Edward Wise (1857-1942), bank clerk.
Aimee Wise [née Selby] (1867-1921), m. (1886) Edward Wise.
Aleck Beeching (1884-1956), electrical engineer.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Charles Loch (1849-1923; ODNB), social worker and secretary, Charity Organisation Society, 1875-1914.
Walter Champernowne (1828-1929), rector, Northleigh, Devon, 1896-1918.
John Macmillan (1877-1956; WWW), resident chaplain, archbishop of canterbury, 1904-15; m. (1906) Anne Maurice, daughter of major-general Frederick Maurice.
Louisa Swinburne [née Stewart] (1862-1960), daughter of Robert Stewart and Margaret Stevenson; m. Thomas Swinburne.

Benjamin Kidd (1858-1916; ODNB), sociologist whose Principles of Western Civilisation (1902) emphasised that providing for the collective well-being of the human race in the future was of greater priority than satisfying individual interests in the present.
George Drowley (1879-1931), accountant.
William Huckstepp (1874-1938), clerk and salesman; m. (1901) Florence Evans.
Marjorie Atkinson (1886-1955), daughter of Dora Stopford and Lt.-Col. Richard Atkinson.
Mabel Cunnington (1888-1953), dressmaker, 1911; m. (1912) Albert Holmes, warehouseman.
Edith Hagger (b. 1886), lived with mother at Dean's Yard coach house, 1901; stenographer, 1911; m. (1923) Edric Wilson.
Marion Prestidge (1887-1977), book keeper at Hamleys, 1911.
Ethel Norris (1884-1979), m. (1914) George Todd.
Ada Bright (b. 1886), servant, 1901.
Charlotte Wilberforce [née Langford] (1840-1909), m. (1865) [Albert] Basil Wilberforce, canon, Westminster.
Herbert Jessel (1866-1950; WWW), 1st Baron Jessel; soldier and politician; MP (LU) St Pancras South, 1896-1906, (C) 1910-18; Mayor of Westminster, 1902-3.

Frederic Thesiger had five male cousins by two of his father's brothers: George Handcock Thesiger (1868-1915), Gerald Thesiger (1872-1947); Arthur Thesiger (1872-1968), Bertram Sackville Thesiger (1875-1966), and Ernest Frederic Thesiger (1879-1961).
Rosalind Wolfe-Barry [née Rowsell] (1846-1937), m. (1874) John Wolfe-Barry.
Percy Allen (1869-1923; ODNB), Erasmian scholar; resigned chair of history, Government College, Lahore, in 1901 on health grounds and returned to Oxford.
Albert Clarke (1888-1916), clerk.
James Sinstadt (1888-1967), motor fitter, 1911.
George Brooks (1888-1965), postman, 1911.
Charles Gounod (1818-1893), French composer.

Edward VI (1537-53; ODNB), the first protestant English sovereign, 1547-53, commonly cited within the Church of England in connection with the two versions of the Book of Common Prayer published during his reign.

Thomas Cranmer (1489-1556; ODNB), responsible as archbishop of Canterbury, 1533-55, for many measures in the English Reformation and for early foundation texts of the Church of England, including the first official ('Great') Bible in English, 1539-40, and the Book of Common Prayer in its original version, 1549, and the more protestant revision of 1552; deprived of office by Queen Mary I, and the leading 'Oxford martyr', burned at the stake.
Emily Saintsbury [née King] (1844-1924), m. (1868) George Saintsbury.
Amy Muir Mackenzie [née Graham] (1852-1900), daughter of William Graham and Jane Lowndes; m. (1874) Kenneth Muir Mackenzie.

Charles Longman (1852-1934; ODNB), partner, Longmans, Green & Co., 1877-1928, publisher with strengths in theology, particularly following the take-over of the house of Rivington, 1890. University Coll., Oxford.
Edward Tait (1890-1910), son of Edward Tait and Frances Emily Willett.

Elizabeth Asquith (1897-1945), daughter of H. H. Asquith and Margot Tennant; prepared for confirmation by Henson, who found her precocious and difficult; m. (1919) Prince Antoine Bibesco, member of the Romanian delegation in London; author of novels, poetry, plays and short stories.
Margaret [Margot] Asquith [née Tennant] (1864-1945; ODNB), m. (1894) Herbert Henry Asquith.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Roger Casement (1864-1916; ODNB), consular posts in Africa and South America, 1884-1912, exposing human rights abuses in the Congo and in Peru, leading the British investigation into the Putumayo atrocities, 1910-11; joined the Irish Volunteer Force, 1913; executed for treason, April 1916, after capture delivering German arms to Ireland by U-boat in 1916; Henson believed his punishment just, refusing to sign a petition for clemency, but was distressed at such a humanitarian's fall from grace: Journal, 25 April 1916.
Stanley Syms (1886-1916), stockbrokers clerk; m. (1914) Jessie Clark; killed in First World War while serving with the Royal Garrison Artillery
Louisa Gore-Booth [née Trench] (1848-1926), daughter of Henry Trench and Georgina Bloomfield; m. (1870) James Gore-Booth.
Mary [Mini] Dennistoun (1870-1945), m. (1896) George Macauley Kirkpatrick, a Canadian who rose to the rank of general in the British Army; Ella's second cousin.
Archibald Parker Smith (1883-1971), 5th laird of Jordanhill; served in the British Army in WWI, retiring at rank of captain, 1920; civil engineer; Ella's second cousin.
Edith Davidson [née Tait] (1858-1936), daughter of Catherine Spooner and Archibald Tait, archbishop of Canterbury (1868-82); m. (1878) Randall Davidson, archbishop of Canterbury (1903-28).
Margaret Anstruther (1887-1925), daughter of Ralph Anstruther of Balcaskie, 6th Bt; prepared for confirmation by Henson.
Magdalen Erskine [née Anstruther] (1889-1953), daughter of Ralph Anstruther of Balcaskie, 6th Bt; prepared for confirmation by Henson; m. (1911) Thomas Erskine of Cambo, 4th Bt.
William Barlow (d. 1613; ODNB), bishop of Lincoln, 1609-13.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Samuel Hall (1841-1907), vice-chancellor, County Palatine of Lancaster, 1895-1905.
John Cheadle (1848-1908), minor canor, Westminster Abbey, 1878-1908; theological tutor, King's Coll., London, 1893-1908.
Ernest John Bennett (b. 1892), choirboy at St Margaret's, Westminster, 1905; mentee and member of Henson's 'Shakesperians'; commercial clerk, export merchant, 1911.
Thomas Walters (1881-1947; CCD), curate, St Margaret's, Westminster, 1906-7, and St Mark, Notting Hill, 1907-9; prebendary of Exeter Cathedral from 1930.
Pamela McKenna [née Jekyll] (1889-1943), niece of gardener Gertrude Jekyll; m. (1908) Reginald McKenna.
Thomas Lough (1850-1922; WWW), MP (L) Islington, W, 1892-1918; founder, Home Rule Union, 1887; HM Lieutenant, Co. Cavan, 1907-22; m. (1880) Edith Mills.
Frances Simmons (1880-1978), m. (1917) Frederick Austin.
Evelyn Merry (1893-1963), shorthand typist.
Dorothy Hunt (1885-1975), m. (1909) William Clifford.
Bertha Lenton (1892-1990), m. (1918) Joseph Thomas Hitchcock.
Henrietta Bingemann (1888-1970), m. (1929) Newton Graeme Driver.
Geraldine Briggs (1889-1945), m. (1st, 1916) Edouard Majolier, (2nd, 1920) Francis Peter Longton.
Frances Chenevix Trench (1847-1941), daughter of Richard Chenevix Trench, archbishop of Dublin, 1863-84.
Thomas Knox (1882-1915), son of Uchter Knox and Constance Caulfield; killed in First World War while serving with the Coldstream Guards.

Herbert Gladstone (1854-1930; ODNB), youngest child of the prime minister; MP (L) Leeds, 1880-1910; chief Liberal whip, 1899-1905; home secretary, 1905-10; viscount, 1910; governor general, South Africa, 1910-14; leading Asquithian Liberal organiser, 1917-30.

Robert Charles (1855-1931; ODNB), church of England clergyman and biblical scholar. Professor of biblical Greek, Trinity Coll., Dublin, 1898-1906; Grinfield lecturer on the Septuagint, Oxford, 1905-11; canon of Westminster, 1913.
Uchter Knox (1856-1933), 5th Earl of Ranfuly; governor of New Zealand, 1897-1904.

Augustine Birrell (1850-1933; ODNB), nonconformist background; essayist; MP (L) North Bristol, 1906-18; president of the board of education, 1905-7, responsible for the 1906 Education bill; chief secretary for Ireland, 1907-16, in charge of the 1912 Irish home rule bill, enacted in 1914; resigned after the Easter Rising.

[James] Ramsay MacDonald (1866-1937; ODNB); early ethical socialist; secretary, Labour representation committee, 1900-6, and Labour party, 1906-11; MP (Lab) Leicester 1906-18, Aberavon, 1922-9, Seaham 1929-31, (Nat Lab) 1931-5, Scottish Universities 1935-7; chairman, Labour parliamentary party, 1911-14, 1922-31; critic of the war, 1914-18, and co-founder of Union of Democractic Control; prime minister and foreign secretary of first Labour government, 1924; prime minister, Labour government, 1929-31, National government 1931-5; lord president of the council, 1935-7.
Thomas James Macnamara (1861-1931; ODNB) executive member, National Union of Teachers; MP (L) North Camberwell, 1900-24; junior minister, 1907-20; minister of Labour, 1920-22.
John Dryden (1631-1700; ODNB), poet, playwright, and critic.
Robert Story (1835-1907; ODNB), Church of Scotland minister and historian of his church; principal, University of Glasgow 1898-1907.
William Ker (1823-1912), merchant.

James Peile (1863-1940; WWW), fellow, chaplain, and praelector, University College, Oxford, 1900-7; vicar, All Saints, Ennismore Gardens, London, 1907-10; rector, Great Comberton, Worcestershire, 1910-17; archdeacon, Warwick, 1910-21, and Worcester, 1921-38.
Thomas Abbott (1829-1913; WWW), fellow of Trinity College, Dublin, 1854-1913; philosopher and bibliographer.
Cecil White (priest, 1886), rector, St Peter's, Hornsey, 1898-1907.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Edgeworth Lenora [Nora] Scott [née Hill] (1842-1924), daughter of Frederick Hill and Martha Cowper; m. (1867) Sir John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; wrote about her life in India; once widowed, lived at 17 Cowley Street, Westminster; remained active in philanthropic and political campaigning, holding salons in her home and publishing frequently in the Times.

Edmund Ludlow (1616-92; ODNB), parliamentary army officer during the English civil war and the protectorate; as an MP, among the signatories of Charles I's death warrant; a fugitive and in exile after the restoration of the monarchy in 1660.

Herbert Paul (1853-1935; ODNB), author and politician; Henson's interest in his Life of Froude (1905) would have been in J. A. Froude's protestant and English patriotic defence of the Reformation, against critics such as E. A. Freeman with their high-church associations.
Sarah Bere [née Griffiths], m. (1902) Montague Acland Bere.
Louise Dawkins [née Johnston] (d. 1940).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Lewis Dibdin (1852-1938; ODNB), ecclesiastical lawyer, judge and administrator, QC 1901; kt. 1903; long-standing member and sometime vice-chairman, house of layman, Canterbury convocation; dean of the arches and master of the faculties, 1903-34; first church estates commissioner, 1905-30; member and draftsman, royal commissions on Ecclesiastical Discipline, 1904-6, and on Divorce, 1909-12, and the archbishops' committee on church and state, 1913-16; member, house of laity and legislative committee, Church Assembly, from 1920; vicar general, Canterbury province, 1925-34.
Malcolm MacColl (1831-1907; ODNB), canon of Ripon, 1884-1907; prominent opponent of the Public Worship Act, 1874, outlawing certain ritualist practices.
George Tallents (1856-1924; WWW), barr. and mayor of the city of Westminster, 1906-7, 1918-19; alderman, Westminster city council.
George Herbert (1593-1633; ODNB), Church of England clergyman, and religious and 'metaphysical' poet.
Pamela Bulwer-Lytton [née Chichele-Plowden], countess of Lytton (1873-1971), wife of the 2nd earl.
Cecil Chapman (1852-1938; WWW), barr. and metropolitan police magistrate, Tower Bridge, 1899-24; Conservative member for Chelsea, LCC, 1896-8.
Adeline Chapman [née Chapman] (d. 1931); m. (1st, 1867) Arthur Guest, (2nd, 1899) Cecil Chapman.
George Newsom (1871-1934; WWW), professor of pastoral theology, King's Coll., London, 1903-17; vicar of Newcastle, 1916-28; master of Selwyn Coll., Cambridge, 1928-34; member of 'the Brotherhood'.
Arthur Scott (1878-1909), son of Edgeworth Hill and John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; worked in the Indian Civil Service.
Jessie Thompson [née Beaumont] (1852-1927).
Leslie Scott (1878-1909; ODNB), son of Edgeworth Hill and John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; judge and politician.

John Harmer (1857-1944; WWW), bishop of Rochester, 1905-30; kept his distance from ecclesiastical controversies: obituary, Times, 10 Mar. 1944, 7; declined to attend Henson's consecration as bishop of Hereford.
John Calvin (1509-74), reform theologian based in Geneva; a leading inspiration for the Scottish presbyterian reformation and for English puritans and subsequent dissenting denominations.
Leonard Courtney (1832-1918; ODNB), Baron Courtney of Penwith (1906), journalist and politician who held office under Gladstone in the early 1880s.

Herbert Lewis (1858-1933; ODNB), a leading Welsh radical nonconformist; MP (L) Flint boroughs 1892-1906, Flintshire, 1906-18; University of Wales 1918-22; junior minister at the Treasury, 1905-9, local government board, 1909-15, board of education, 1915-22.

Thomas McKinnon Wood (1855-1927; WWW), 'progressive' member, London county council, 1892-1909, chairman, 1898-9; MP (L) Glasgow St Rollox, 1906-18; junior minister, board of education, 1908, foreign office, 1908-11, Treasury, 1911-12; secretary for Scotland 1912-16; chancellor, duchy of Lancaster 1916.

David W. Forrest (1856-1918; WWW), minister in United Presbyterian Church, 1892-1900, then United Free Church (at North Morningside, Edinburgh, 1903-14); professor of systematic theology and apologetics, United Free Church College, Glasgow, 1914-18; preacher and biblical expositor with an international reputation; his publications included The authority of Christ (Edinburgh, 1906).
Margaret Pember [née Davey] (1868-1942), daughter of Horace, Baron Davey; m. (1895) Francis Pember; twin of Beatrix Gatacre, and it was through the Pembers that Henson met Gatacre.

Beatrix Gatacre [née Davey] (1868-1938), daughter of Horace, Baron Davey; m. (1895) William Gatacre; author of his biography, General Gatacre: The story of the life and services of Sir William Forbes Gatacre (1910); her twin, Margaret married a close friend of Henson, Francis Pember.

Horace Davey (1833-1907; ODNB), Baron Davey (1894), barrister; MP (L), Christchurch, 1881-5, Stockton-on-Tees, 1888-92; solicitor general, 1886; judge, 1893; father of the wives of two of Henson's friends, Francis Pember and William Gatacre.
Louisa Davey [née Donkin], m. (1862) Horace, Baron Davey.
Alfonso XIII (1886-1941), reigned 1886-1931.
Victoria Eugenie of Battenburg (1887-1969), a niece of Edward VII, m. (1906) Alfonso of Spain.
William Appleton Lawrence (1889-1968), third bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Western Massachussetts, 1937-57.
Mary Duclaux Darmesteter [née Robinson] (1857-1944; ODNB), writer; m. (1st, 1888) James Darmesteter, (2nd, 1901) Emile Duclaux, biologist.
Julia Lawrence [née Cunningham] (1853-1927), m. (1874) William Lawrence, bishop of Massachusetts, 1893-1927.
Harriette Parker [née Mead-Waldo] (1885-1962), m. (1st, 1906) Charles Sandbach Parker, (2nd, 1924) Percy Roycroft Lowe, ornithologist and surgeon.
Frederick Baggallay (1855-1928; WWW), hon. canon, Peterborough, 1903-5; rector, Pulborough, 1904-21.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Mabel Georgina Palmer (1884-1958), daughter of 2nd earl of Selborne.

Charles Robert Grey (1879-1963; WWW), viscount Howick, 1894, 5th earl Grey, 1917; lay churchman; member of the Church Assembly from 1920 (chairman, 1946-55); chairman of the Church of England's Central Board of Finance.

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Dickson-Poynder (1866-1936; ODNB), baron Islington, 1910; MP (C) Chippenham 1892-1905, (L) 1905-10; governor-general, New Zealand, 1910-12.
Hugh Arnold-Forster (1855-1909; ODNB), politician and author; MP (LU) West Belfast, 1902-1906; Croydon (U) 1906-9; secretary of state for war, 1903-6.

Richard Haldane (1856-1928; ODNB), viscount Haldane (1911), politician, educationist, and philosopher, rooted in the Idealist thought he had imbibed as a student at Gottingen; MP (L) Haddingtonshire, 1885-1911; secretary of state for war, 1905-12, responsible for extensive army reform; lord chancellor, 1912-15; lost office due to campaign in the press against his German sympathies; lord chancellor in the first Labour government, 1924; his posthumously published autobiography much admired by Henson: Henson to Elizabeth Haldane, 16 Feb. 1929, HHH109/70.
Helen Bridge [née Amphlett] (d. 1906), m. (1883) [John] Frederick Bridge.
William Reed Huntington (1838-1909), priest in the Episcopal Church of the USA; served Grace Church, New York City, 1883-1909.
St John Brodrick (1856-1942; ODNB), MP (C) West Surrey 1880-1906, and Unionist cabinet minister, 1900-5; 9th viscount Midleton, 1907.
Henry Chaplin (1840-1923; ODNB), MP (C) Mid-Lincolnshire, 1868-1906, Wimbledon, 1907-16; cabinet posts, 1885-6, 1889-92, 1895-1900; 1st viscount Chaplin, 1916.
John Selden (1584-1654; ODNB), lawyer and historical and linguistic scholar.
Henry Augustus Candy (1842-1911), British military officer.

Richard Hooker (1554-1600; ODNB), theologian and philosopher, much admired by Henson for his conception of a latitudinarian national church: see Braley, More Letters, 107-8. Henson read Hooker's Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity (1593-7) early in his career (Journal, 27 Apr. 1888) and during the passage of the Enabling Act defended the continued validity of Hooker's conception of the Church as a national institution rather than a mere denomination: 'The Church of England', 22 June 1919, in In Defence of the Church of England (1923).
Henry Pelham-Clinton, 7th duke of Newcastle (1864-1928; WWW); his father-in-law was Major Henry Candy (1842-1911; WWW).
Richard Hedger (b. 1852), night foreman, Beckton Gas Works, Barking, 1911.

Algernon Lawley (1857-1931; WWW), 5th baron Wenlock (1918). Eton Missioner, Hackney Wick, 1881-6; chaplain, St Andrew's, Bethnal Green, 1886-96; rector, St John at Hackney, 1897-1911; prebendary, St Paul's Cathedral, 1907-23; incumbent, St Peter's, Eaton Square, 1913-16.
Frederick Newland (1859-1938), Claremont Central Mission, Pentonville, 1902-1909; secretary, Congregational Board, 1910-24.
Reginald Welby (1832-1915; ODNB), permanent secretary of the Treasury, 1885-94; baron Welby, 1894.

Title: Sir
Narrative: William Bilsland (1847-1921; ODNB), bread and biscuit manufaturer; lord provost, University of Glasgow, 1905-8; member, United Free Church.
Emily Buchanan [née Bolitho] (1851-1942), daughter of Thomas Bolitho, deputy warden of the Stannaries and high sheriff of Cornwall; m. (1888) Thomas Ryburn Buchanan.
George John Shaw-Lefevre (1831-1928; ODNB), politician; Baron Eversley of Old Ford, 1906.
Constance Shaw-Lefevre [née Moreton] (d. 1920).
Richard Curzon (1861-1929; WWW), 4th earl Howe; posts in royal court, 1896-1925; m. (1st) Georgiana Spencer-Churchill (1860-1906), daughter of 7th duke of Marlborough.

John Buchan (1875-1940; ODNB), Scottish author, and barrister, publisher and public servant, with strong Oxford connections; MP (C), Scottish Universities, 1927-35; Baron Tweedsmuir of Elsfield, 1935; governor-general, Canada, 1935-40; a Church of Scotland elder at St. Columba's Church, London, and in Oxford; high commissioner to the general assembly of the Church of Scotland, 1933-4; author of novels, biographies, histories and 'thrillers', notably The Thirty-nine steps (1915). His works mentioned by Henson include Nelson's history of the war, 24 vols (Feb. 1915-July 1919) in 50,000 word instalments; A book of escapes and hurried journeys (1922); and, with George Adam Smith,The Kirk in Scotland, 1560-1929 (1930).

Ralph Vaughan Williams (1872-1958; ODNB), composer and folksong collector; central figure in the early twentieth-century English musical renaissance; musical editor of The English Hymnal (1906), a major contribution to English hymnody and congregational participation in worship.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Edward Maunde Thompson (1840-1929; ODND), director and principal librarian, British Museum, 1898-1909; founding fellow, British Academy, and president, 1907-9.
Thomas Hodgkin (1831-1913; ODNB), historian of Italy; founding fellow, British Academy.

Walter Runciman (1870-1949; ODNB), MP (L) Oldham, 1899-1900, Dewsbury, 1902-18, Swansea West, 1924-29, and St Ives, 1929-37 (from 1931, Liberal National); a shipowner, Wesleyan methodist, and teetotaller; parliamentary secretary, local government board, 1905-7; financial secretary, Treasury, 1907-8; president of the board of education 1908-11, the board of agriculture, 1911-14, and the board of trade, 1914-16, 1931-7; 1st viscount Runciman, 1937; mission to Czechoslovakian government during the Sudeten crisis, 1938; lord president of the council, 1938-9.
John Harrison-Broadley (d. 1944), son of William Henry Harrison-Broadley, MP (C), East Riding, Yorkshire, 1868-85.
Rosalind Harrison-Broadley [née Dugdale] (c. 1887-1997).
Edward Johnson-Ferguson (1849-1929; WWW), MP (L), Loughborough, 1885-6. 1892-1900; 1st bt. (1906).
Williamina Johnson-Ferguson [née Cunningham] (1849-1937), daughter of William Alexander Cunningham, J.P.; m. (1874) Edward Johnson-Ferguson, 1st Bt.
Cathcart Wason (1848-1921; WWW), MP in New Zealand, 1870s-90s; on return to Scotland, MP (LU), Orkney and Shetland, 1900-2; (Ind. L), 1902-6; (L), 1906-21.
[James] Henry Dalziel (1868-1935; ODNB), MP (L) Kirkcaldy, 1892-1921; journalist and owner of Reynold's News, 1914-21, and Pall Mall Gazette, 1917-21; baron Dalziel, 1921.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Francis Curruthers Gould (1844-1925; ODNB), stockbroker and political cartoonist, principally for the Westminster Gazette, 1893-1914; Kt, 1906.
Lucy Hicks Beach [née Fortescue], countess St Aldwyn (d. 1940), second wife (m. 1874) of Michael Hicks Beach, 1st earl St Aldwyn.
William Fitchett (1841-1928), Methodist minister and journalist, Victoria, Australia, who had emigrated with his family from Lincolnshire in 1854.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Percy Bunting (1836-1911; ODNB), social reformer and journal editor, active in the Methodist movement; editor, Contemporary Review, 1882-1911; Kt, 1908.
(probably) William Meiklejohn (1845-1909; WWW), served in India, Afghanistan, Egypt, Malakand; major-general; KCB, 1898.
Elsie Shaw [née Stephen] (d. 1939).
Thomas Shaw (1850-1937; ODNB), lawyer, QC 1894; MP (L), Hawick, 1892-1909; lord advocate, 1905-9; lord of appeal and Baron Shaw of Dunfermline, 1909; 1st Baron Craigmyle, 1929.

John Simon (1873-1954; ODNB), son of a Congregationalist minister; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1897; barr., KC 1908; MP (L) Walthamstow, 1906-18, Spen Valley, 1922-40 (from 1931, Liberal National); kt., 1910; solicitor-general, 1910-13, attorney-general 1913-15; home secretary, 1915-16, resigning in protest against conscription; Asquithian opponent of Lloyd George, and leader of Liberal National party, 1931-40; foreign secretary, 1931-5; home secretary, 1935-7; chancellor of the exchequer, 1937-40, lord chancellor, 1940-5.

John Scott Lidgett (1854-1953; ODNB), Wesleyan Methodist minister; founder and warden, Bermondsey Settlement, 1891-1949; editor, Methodist Times, 1908-18, and Contemporary Review; chairman of the Methodist Conference, 1908-9; prominent in the London Council, and in management of the University of London; president, National Free Church Council, 1906, hon. secretary 1914-40; moderator, Federal Free Church Council, 1923-4; conciliatory on denominational issues, and a friend and ally of Archbishop Davidson.
Frederick Dixon-Hartland (1832-1909; WWW), MP (C), Uxbridge, 1885-1909.
Christian IX (1818-1906), king of Denmark, 1863-1906; as brother of Queen Alexandra and so brother-in-law of Edward VII, honoured by a memorial service in Westminster Abbey.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Wilfred Lawson (1829-1906; WWW), 2nd bt.; MP (L) since 1859, latterly for Camborne 1903-6, Cockermouth, 1906.
Andrew Milne (c.1830-1906), Church of Scotland minister, Fyvie, 1870-1906; moderator of general assembly, 1905-6.
Andrew Fairbairn (1838-1912; ODNB), Congregational minister and college head; founding principal, Mansfield Coll., Oxford; founding member, British Academy.
Hannah Lawrence [née Cobb] (1891-1977).

George Curzon (1859-1925; ODNB), baron Curzon 1898, earl 1911, marquess, 1916. Fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford, 1883, and a member of Henson's Layman's League; MP (C) Southport, 1886-99; under-secretary, foreigh office, 1895-99; viceroy of India, 1899-1905; chancellor, Univ. of Oxford, 1907-25; rector, Univ. of Glasgow, 1908-11; Irish representative peer, house of lords 1908-16; lord privy seal, 1915-16; lord president of the council, 1916-19; foreign secretary, 1919-24; lord president of the council, 1924-5.

William Addis (1844-1917; WWW), Anglican who became a Roman Catholic; ordained 1872; professor of Old Testament criticism, Manchester Coll., Oxford, 1898-1910; returned to Church of England, 1901; permission to officiate as Anglican priest, 1907; vicar of All Saints, Ennismore Gardens, 1910-17.
Samuel Taylor (1859-1929; WWW), archdeacon of Southwark, 1904-21.

John Wallace Suter (1859-1942), rector, Church of the Epiphany, Winchester, Massachussetts, 1885-1912; member, commission on revision and enrichment of the Prayer Book of the Episcopal Church of the USA, 1913-42.
Walter Morgan (1831-1916; WWW), 1st baronet (1906); Lord Mayor of the City of London, 1905-6.
Watson Failes (1847-1920), mathmatics master, Westminster School, 1877-1907; vicar, Willoughby, Warwickshire, 1907-13; vicar, Ashbury, Berkshire, 1913-20.
George Congreve (1835-1918; CCD), ord. 1859; Society of St John the Evangelist, 1875; resident priest at 22, Great College Street, Westminster.

Roundell Palmer, Lord Wolmer (1887-1971; ODNB), baron Selborne 1940, 3rd earl of Selborne 1942. MP (C) Newtown, 1910-18, Aldershot 1918-40; junior minister, 1922-23, 1924-29; a leading lay churchman; member, Archbishops' Committee on Church and State, 1913-16; secretary, Church Self-Government Association, 1917-20; parliamentary manager of the Enabling bill, 1919; long-serving member, houses of laity of Canterbury Convocation and Church Assembly; member, parliamentary Ecclesiastical Committee from 1920.
Frederick Ramsay (1884-1918), solicitor's clerk; churchwarden's clerk, St Margaret's, Westminster.
Rosalind Maitland [née Sellar] (d. 1959), daughter of Alexander Sellar, MP (L), 1882-6, (LU), 1886-90.
Alexander Maitland (1877-1965; WWW), Scottish barr., 1903; Kt. 1963.
Mary Curzon [née Leiter] (1870-1906; ODNB), m. George Curzon, 1895.

Ivy Muriel Chamberlain [née Dundas] (1878-1941), m. (1906) Joseph Austen Chamberlain; created Dame of the British Empire, 1925, in recognition of her efforts, alongside her husband while he was Foreign Secretary, to establish the Locarno Pact; campaigned to raise awareness and relief for women and children caught up in the Spanish Civil War.
Elizabeth Cheylesmore [née Richardson] (1861-1945).

Henry Bovey (1850-1912; WWW), chair of civil engineering and applied mechanics, McGill University, 1878-1909; dean, faculty of applied sciences, McGill University, 1879-1909; founding member, Canadian Society of Civil Engineers; rector, Imperial College of Science and Technology, London, 1909.
Emily Bovey [née Redpath] (1853-1941), m. (1880) Henry Bovey; sister of Margaret Dennistoun.
Helen Suter [née Jenkins] (1864-1942), m. (1888) John Wallace Suter.
Adela Kate Bankhead (b. 1874), milliner.

Brooke Foss Westcott (1825-1901; ODNB), clergyman and prolific biblical scholar; translator (with F. J. Hort) of the Greek New Testament, and contributor to the Revised Version of the Bible (both 1881); a Christian socialist; first president of the Christian Social Union, 1889; as bishop of Durham, 1890-1901, established close relations with miners' union and other bodies of workmen, and in 1892 famously mediated a settlement of a miners' strike.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Jeanette [Jennie] Spencer-Churchill [née Jerome] (1854-1921), American-born socialite and writer; m. (1874) Randolph Churchill; mother of Winston Churchill.
Martin Morris Killanin (1867-1927; WWW), 2nd baron Killanin; public servant and MP (C), Galway, 1900-1.
James Hills-Johnes (1833-1919; WWW), army officer; VC, 1858; KCB, 1881.
Leonard Shelford (1836-14; WWW), vicar, St Martin-in-the-Fields, 1903-14.
Robert Hadden (1854-1909; WWW), vicar, St Mark's, North Audley Street, 1899-1909.

Robert Crew-Milnes (1858-1945; ODNB), Liberal politician; Marquis of Crewe, 1911; lord president of the council, 1905-8, colonial secretary, 1908-10, secretary for India, 1910-1915, lord president of the council, 1915-16, president, board of education, 1916; Liberal leader, house of lords 1908-23 and 1936-44; secretary of state for air, 1931.
Hannah Lang [née Keith] (1840-1921), m. (1861) John Marshall Lang.

William Burdett-Coutts [né Bartlett] (1851-1921; ODNB), m. (1881) the much older and very wealthy baroness Burdett-Coutts, adopting her name; assisted and continued her philanthropic work; MP (U) Westminster, 1885-1918; Abbey, Westminster, 1918-21.
Ellen Thorneycroft Fowler (1860-1929; ODNB), novelist. Won public recognition for her novel Concerning Isobel Carnoby (1898); m. Alfred Felkin, 1903.
Sophia Plummer (b. 1823).
Julia Ballard (1839-1922).
James Graham, 1st marquess of Montrose (1612-50; ODNB), royalist captain-general of Scotland during the civil wars; captured by covenantor forces in 1650, and executed.
David Leslie (1601-82; ODNB); general in the Scottish covenanter army; 1st baron Newark, 1661.
Marian Bell [née Sandeman] (1837-1914), second wife (m. 1872) of Henry Glassford Bell; friend to the Hensons, often hosting the couple while they travelled in Scotland.
David Heggie (1874-1917; FES), minister of Monzievaird and Strowan, 1903-17.
Louis Duchesne (1843-1922), French priest and historian; director of French School in Rome; associated with Roman Catholic modernism.

Title: Pope Pius X
Narrative: As Pius X (1903-14), Guiseppe Sarto struggled with a crisis in Catholic theology following attempts to reconcile Catholicism with new currents of thought. Opposed to intellectualism, he undertook a ruthless suppression of Modernism, culminating in a 'anti-Modernist oath' in 1910, regular subscription to which was required of all Roman Catholic clergy.
Alfred Loisy (1857-1940), Roman Catholic priest and theologian, widely regarded as the founder of modernism in the Roman Catholic Church; excommunicated in March 1908.
George Tyrrell (1861-1909), Irish Jesuit priest and modernist theologian, dismissed by the Jesuits in 1906 and excommunicated in 1908.
Basil Maturin (1847-1915; ODNB), Roman Catholic priest and religious writer; convert from Anglicanism (Cowley Fathers).
Hugh Benson (1871-1914; ODNB), Roman Catholic priest and writer; son of Edward White Benson, archbishop of Canterbury.
Robert Dennistoun (1837-1915), son of James Robert Dennistoun and Barbara Macredie; naval career, appointed vice-admiral on the retired list, 1896; distant relation to Ella.
Francis Marion Crawford (1854-1909), novelist.

Gilbert Henson (1866-1947), Henson's brother; moved to Canada, 1886, after a brief time in India with brother, Arthur; eventually settled in Penticton, British Columbia; fruit rancher; m. (1901) Lois Binnington.
Walter Henson (1853-1906), Henson's brother; moved to Canada by the early 1880s, eventually settling in Lethbridge, Alberta; general store operator; m. (1881) Eliza Thetford.

Harold Henson (1891-1958), Henson's nephew; son of Walter Henson and Eliza Thetford; m. (1922) Bertha Merriman; architect; Henson corresponded with his nephew throughout his lifetime, a relationship strengthened by Harold's furlough visitations to the Hensons while serving in the Canadian Expeditionary Forces during WWI; Henson served as godfather to Harold's son, Walter.
[Sarah] Charlotte Campbell Bannerman [née Bruce] (d. 1906), wife of the Liberal politican and prime minister, Henry Campbell Bannerman.

Walter Cariss (priest, 1896; CCD), vicar, St Gabriel's, Birmingham, who appealed to Charles Gore, bishop of Birmingham, to prevent Henson from preaching at Carr's Lane Congregational chapel in his parish.
Reginald Talbot (1862-1935; WWW), canon of Bristol, 1906-28.
Hubert Carr-Gomm (1877-1939), MP (L), Rotherhithe division of Southwark, 1906-18; assistant private secretary, Henry Campbell-Bannerman, 1906-8.
Kathleen Carr-Gomm [née] Rome (1887-1949); m. Hubert Carr-Gomm, 1906; divorced in 1913, following an affair with Liberal MP, Eliot Crawshay-Williams.

Title: Sir
Narrative: James Dundas-Grant (1854-1944; WWW), aurist and laryngologist, Nose, Throat, and Ear Hospital, Gray's Inn Road, 1879; KBE, 1920.
William Gordon McCabe (1841-1920), soldier, scholar, and author.
Richard Busby (1606-95; ODNB), headmaster, Westminster School, 1638, 1640-95, and canon of the Abbey, where he is buried.
William Mohne Blandford (ord. 1870; CCD), vicar, Sutton St Nicholas, or Lutton, 1894.
James Macarthur (1848-1922; WWW), bishop of Bombay, 1898-1903; bishop suffragan of Southampton, 1903-20.
Charles Bigg (1840-1908; ODNB), schoolmaster and regius professor of ecclesiastical history, Oxford, 1901-8.

John Dalberg-Acton (1834-1902; ODNB), 1st baron Acton , historian and liberal Roman catholic essayist, notable for his aphorisms; regius professor of modern history, Univ. of Cambridge, 1895-1902; his works included A lecture on the study of history (1895) and, posthumously, Lectures on modern history (1906), History of freedom and other essays (1907) and Lectures on the French revolution (1910).

James Frazer (1854-1941; ODNB), social anthropologist and classical scholar, author of The Golden Bough (2 vols., 1890), portraying religion as a necessary but primitive form of belief in the development of the human mind; and Adonis, Attis, Osiris: studies in the history of oriental religion (1907); Kt, 1914.
Evelyn Cavendish [née Petty-FitzMaurice] (1870-1960), m. (1892) Victor Cavendish, 9th duke of Devonshire.

Norman Straton (1840-1918; ODNB), bishop of Sodor and Man, 1892-1907, and of Newcastle, 1907-15; an evangelical who was unpopular in the Newcastle diocese, which was developing an Anglo-Catholic character, and which he failed to approach sensitivily.

Margaret Dennistoun [née Redpath] (1836-1906), daughter of Jane Drummond and John Redpath, contractor, industrialist, and founder of the Canadian Sugar Refining Company; m. (1866) Alexander Dennistoun.

James Mitford Mitchell (1843-1914; WWW), Church of Scotland minister; a royal chaplain in Scotland, 1888-1914; in retirement, convenor, colonial committee of the general assembly, 1898-1909, and moderator, 1907; keen advocate of union with the United Free Church.
Dugald Butler (1862-1926; WWW), minister, Tron Church, Edinburgh, 1902-7, and Galashiels from 1907; historian of the Church of Scotland and Scottish religion.
[James] Cameron Lees (1834-1913; WWW), minister, St Giles' Cathedral, Edinburgh, 1877-1909; royal chaplain, 1881-1913.
Robert Fisher (1861-1934; WWW), minister, Morningside Church, Edinburgh, 1900-14, St. Cuthberts, Edinburgh, 1914-25.

Andrew Wallace Williamson (1856-1926; WWW), Churhc of Scotland minister, St Cuthbert's, Edinburgh, 1883-1909, and St Giles, Edinburgh, 1910-25; dean of the Order of the Thistle and the Chapel Royal in Scotland.

William Paterson Paterson (1860-1939; ODNB), theologian and minister of the Church of Scotland; professor of divinity, Edinburgh University, 1903-34; a royal chaplain in Scotland, 1916-39; moderator, general assembly, 1919; prominent in union with the United Free Church; Gifford lecturer, 1923-5; see The diaries of William Paterson Paterson, ed. C. Rawlins (Edinburgh, 1987).
Alice Shaw-Stewart [née Thynne] (c. 1863-1942), m. (1883) Hugh Shaw-Stewart.
Katherine Baring [née Thynne] (1865-1933), m. (1901) 1st earl of Cromer.
[Michael] Hugh Shaw-Stewart (1854-1942; WWW), 8th baronet (1903), MP (C), East Renfrewshire, 1886-1906.
George Campbell, 8th duke of Argyll (1823-1900; ODNB), cabinet minister in coalition and Liberal governments, 1852-81; a notable natural and political scientist.

William Mathieson (1868-1938; ODNB), historian; author of Politics and religion: a study in Scottish history from the Reformation to the Revolution (2 vols., 1902) and Scotland and the Union, 1695-1747 (1905).
John Spottiswoode (1565-1639: ODNB), archbishop of Glasgow, 1603-15, and St Andrews, 1615-39; lord chancellor 1635-8; author of the posthumous The history of church and state in Scotland (1655).
Edward Cardwell (1787-1861; ODNB), Camden professor of ancient history, Oxford, and ecclesiastical historian; his works include Synodalia (2 vols., 1842).
Thomas Jacombe (1623/4-87; ODNB), presbyterian minister, ejected from St Martin, Ludgate, for nonconformity in 1662; his publications include A treatise of holy dedication (1668).
Jeremy Collier (1650-1726; ODNB), bishop of the nonjuring Church of England and opponent of the theatre; his works include An ecclesiastical history of Great Britain (2vols., 1708, 1714).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Thomas Browne (1605-82; ODNB), physician and author; his most famous work Religio medici (1642), reflects on the paradoxes of and mysteries of Christianity from an English religious perspective.

Benjamin Jowett (1817-93; ODNB), master of Balliol Coll., Oxford, 1870-93; classical scholar and liberal theologian; his published writings include Theological writings of the late Benjamin Jowett, ed. Lewis Campbell (1906).
George Webb (ord. 1899; CCD), curate, Holy Trinity, Sloane Street, 1904-7.
Gathorne Gathorne-Hardy (1814-1906; ODNB), 1st earl of Cranbrook; cabinet minister in successive Conservative governments from 1866 to 1892.
George Wilkinson (1833-1907; ODNB), bishop of Truro, 1883-93; Scottish episcopal bishop of St Andrews, Dunkeld, and Dunblane, 1893-1907.
Irton Smith (1855-1933; WWW), vicar, St Margaret's, Ilkley, 1890-1908.

George Mackarness (1885-1957), theatrical business manager living in Wandsworth in 1911; son of George Evelyn Mackarness, major, Derby regiment; nephew of John Mackarness, by whom Henson was ordained.

John Mackarness (1820-89; ODNB), bishop of Oxford, 1870-88; in his Journal, Henson wrote that the bishop 'quite won my heart by his kindness' during his interview with him before his ordination: Retrospect, I, 25.
William Dawson (CCD; ord. 1862), curate, St Mary the Virgin, Loughton, 1904.

Priscilla McLaren [née Bright] (1815-1906; ODNB), social reformer, anti-slavery and women's rights campaigner; sister of politician John Bright (1811-1889) and temperance activist and suffragette Margaret Bright Lucas (1818-1890).
Edward King (1829-1910; ODNB), bishop of Lincoln, 1885-1910; cleared of alleged ritualist offences by a special court of the archbishop of Canterbury in 1888.

Title: Lady
Narrative: Louise Acheson [née Montagu] (1856-1944), lady of the bedchamber to Queen Alexandra, 1901-25.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Charles Lyall (1845-1920; ODNB), administrator in India and orientalist; KCSI, 1897.
Arthur Lionel Smith (1850-1924; ODNB), historian and master of Balliol Coll., Oxford, 1916-24; member, Archbishops' Committee on Church and State, 1913-16.
Robert Raper (1842-1915; ODNB), fellow and classics tutor, Trinity Coll., Oxford, 1871-1915.

William Temple (1881-1944; ODNB), son of Frederick Temple, archbishop of Canterbury, 1896-1902; lecturer in philosophy, Queen's Coll., Oxford, 1904-10; president, Workers Educational Association, 1908-24; after modernist doubts, ord. 1908; headmaster, Repton School, 1910-14; member, archbishops' commitee on church and state, 1913-16; rector, St James's, Piccadilly, 1914-17, resigning to lead the LIfe and Liberty movement, 1917-19; canon of Westminster, 1919-21; bishop of Manchester, 1921-9; chairman of protestant interdenominational conference, COPEC, 1924; archbishop of York, 1929-42; archbishop of Canterbury, 1942-4; a leading Christian socialist, ecumenicalist, and theologian, his many writings include <i>Church and Nation<i/>(1915) and <i>Christianity and the State<i/>(1928); did not criticise Henson's appointment to Hereford, but they were divided on most Church questions.
Richard Newcourt (d. 1716), public notary and author of Repertorium ecclesiasticum parochiale Londinense: an ecclesiastical parochial history of the diocese of London (2 vols, 1708, 1710).
William Sloane (1850-1928), American historian; works include The life of Napoleon Bonaparte (4 vols., 1896).

Alice Gardner (1854-1927; ODNB), lecturer Newnham Coll., Cambridge, 1884-1914, specialising in Byzantine history; historical department, foreign office, 1914-15; head of history department, Bristol University, 1914-18; author of Letters to a godchild on the catechism and confirmation (1906).
Allen Edwards (1844-1917; WWW), canon of Southwark, 1905-17; proctor in Convocation for Southwark diocese, 1905-17.
Annie Bowlby [née Gedge] (1863-1949).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Francis Channing (1841-1926; WWW), barr. and public servant specialising in agriculture; bt, 1906; Baron Channing of Wellingborough, 1912.

Alexander Bruce (1849-1921; ODNB), 6th Lord Balfour of Burleigh; Scottish representative peer, as a Conservative, 1876-1921; secretary for Scotland, 1895-1903; Unionist free trader; governor, Bank of Scotland, 1904-21; a leading layman in the Church of Scotland, as member of its general assembly from the 1880s led its defence of the Church's establishment, while promoting union with the Free and later United Free Church; president of the World Missionary Conference, Edinburgh, 1910; 'perhaps the most outstanding figure in the public life of Scotland' (ODNB).
Spencer Walpole (1839-1907; ODNB), historian and civil servant; KCB, 1898.
Edward Tait (1857-1939), medical doctor; parishioner at St. Margaret's, Westminster; m. (1890) Frances Emily Willett.
Frances Tait [née Willett], wife of Edward Tait; parishioner at St. Margaret's, Westminster.
Dorothy Gladstone [née Paget] (1876-1953).
Frederic Harrison (1831-1923; ODNB), positivist and author; works include The Creed of a Layman (1907).

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Walton (1852-1908; WWW), MP (L) South Leeds, 1892-1908; attorney-general, 1905-8.

Henry Scott Holland (1847-1918; ODNB), theologian and social reformer; canon, St Paul's Cathedral, 1884-1910; co-founder, Christian Social Union, which sought to spread Christian socialist ideas within and beyond the Church; he preached in a thundering and verbose style.
James Trevaskis (ord. 1880; CCD), vicar, St Luke's, Southampton, 1899-1924.
Katharine Asquith [née Horner] (1885-1976), after her husband was killed in action in 1916, she converted to Roman catholicism and became a noted Catholic hostess at her historic home at Mells.
Marcell Conran (1863-1945), ord. 1888; Society St John the Evangelist.

William Lethaby (1857-1931; ODNB), educationist and architect; active in the Arts and Crafts movement; professor of ornament and design, Royal College of Art, South Kensington, 1900-11; surveyor to the fabric of Westminster Abbey, 1906-27.
Lilian Jones (1887-1944), m. (1909) Reginald Goss-Custard.
Mary Scott (1883-1973), daughter of Edgeworth Hill and John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; medical doctor; m. (1915) Alan Radford; close friend of the Hensons.

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Clark (1821-1910; WWW), 2nd baronet (1870), vice-lieutenant of Aberdeenshire.
Gilbert Box (1890-1973), market clerk; wounded in First World War; m. (1919) Frances Castle.
Mary Catherine [Kitty] Inge [née Spooner] (1880-1949), daughter of Catherine Goodwin and Henry Maxwell Spooner, archdeacon of Maidstone; m. (1905) William Ralph Inge.
Arthur Rutty (b. 1847), ord. 1871; headmaster of St John's Foundation School, Leatherhead, 1883.
George Russell (1853-1919; ODNB), politician and writer; active lay member of the Church and Christian socialist.
Charles Bolton (1844-1918; WWW), prebendary, Dassat Parva, Lichfield Cathedral.
Gabrielle Mackarness [née Dawson] (b. 1891), actress.
Abram Smythe Palmer (1844-1917), Irish priest and lecturer, Trinity College Dublin; lexicographer and mythographer.
[probably] Edward Lacy Challenor (1873-1935; WWW), capt., Leicestershire regiment, 1901-1912.
Ernest Wilberforce (1840-1907; ODNB), bishop of Newcastle, 1882-95; bishop of Chichester, 1895-1907.
Charles Ridgeway (1841-1927; WWW), dean of Carlisle, 1905-8; bishop of Chichester, 1908-19.
John Stocks (1843-1926; WWW), archdeacon of Leicester, 1899-1920.

Jean Bruce (1879-1939), daughter of 6th Baron Balfour of Burleigh. Henson was captivated by her 'gravity' and 'sweetness', writing that 'it is long since I met a girl who seemed so eminently worth knowing' and referring to her as his 'Princess of Holyrood: Journal, 24, 22 May 1907; woman of the bedchamber to Queen Mary, 1935-9.
Malcolm III (d. 1093; ODNB), king of the Scots.

Mary Ward [née Arnold] (1851-1920; ODNB), novelist, philanthropist, political lobbyist, and anti-suffragist; established her reputation as a novelist, under the name Mrs Humphry Ward, with Robert Elsmere(1888), whose eponymous character was modelled on the philospher T.H. Green.
Hannah Lang (1870-1952), daughter of John Marshall Lang and Hannah Keith; m. Robert Barclay, minister of West Parish, Greenock.

Francis Bourne (1861-1935; ODNB), Roman catholic bishop of Southwark, 1897-1903; archbishop of Westminster, 1903-35; cardinal, 1911; won conservative (and Henson's) admiration as the only church leader to condemn the General Strike of 1926 as categorically a 'sin'.
Edward (c. 1003-5-1066), king of England; St Edward, known as Edward the Confessor; responsible for the rebuilding of what became Westminster Abbey.

Elizabeth Gully [née Selby] (1839-1906), viscountess Selby; m. (1865) William Gully, who was speaker of the house of commons, 1895-1905, and made viscount Selby 1905 (taking his title from Elizabeth's family name).
John Aird (1833-1911; ODNB), baronet (1901), civil engineering contractor; his many works included the Aswan Dam; churchwarden, St John's, Southwick Gardens.
Louis Phillipe I (1773-1850), king of France, 1830-48; abdicated during the 1848 Revolution.
Augusta Fleet [née Redpath] (1850-1910), daughter of John Redpath and Jane Drummond; sister to Margaret Dennistoun and Emily Bovey; m. (1884) Charles Fleet.
Jane Fleet (1886-1973), daughter of Charles Fleet and Augusta Redpath.
Arthur Deane (1837-1926; WWW), canon, Chichester Cathedral, 1897-1923.

Alfred Emmott (1858-1926; ODNB), cotton manufacturer; MP (L) Oldham, 1899-1911; chairman of committees, house of commons, 1906-11; under-secretary of state, colonies, 1911-14; baron Emmott, 1911: first commissioner of works, 1914-15; director, war trade department, 1915-18.
Sholto Campbell (1839-1916; WWW), 2nd Baron Blythswood (1908), rector, St Silas, Glasgow, 1887-99.
Margaret Proby [n e Hely Hutchinson] (1857-1937), m. (1882) Douglas James Proby.
Douglas [Hamilton] Proby (1856-1931; WWW), British soldier and politician. MP, Saffron Walden, 1910; changed his surname in 1904 from Hamilton to his mother's name, Proby.
Rosina Drew [née Douglas] (1811-1912), daughter of William Douglas and Rosina Service; m. (1854) Peter Drew; resided at Ardencaple House in Row, Dumbartonshire; local benefactor.

LastName: de Castelvecchio Richardson [née Palamidessi de Castelvecchio]
Narrative: Linetta de Castelvechhio Richardson [née Palamidessi de Castelvecchio] (1880-1975), teacher of Italian, Cheltenham Coll., 1897-1903; her friendships with Henson and Inge sparked an interest in clerical modernism and her conversion from catholicism to anglicanism; head of Italian, King's Coll., London, 1915-22; professor of Italian, Birmingham University, 1921-46; m. (1929) Robert Richardson, canon, Birmingham.

Nora Marion Gordon [Ranee] Scott (1882-1982), daughter of Edgeworth Hill and John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; m. (1916) Alan Pim, economist, advisor to the Colonial Office, and co-founder of Oxfam.
Henry Gratton Guinness (1835-1910; ODNB), evangelist and trainer of missionaries.
Reginald [Reggie] Still (1894-1916), bank clerk; killed in First World War while serving with the 9th battalion Royal Fusiliers.

Violet Markham (1872-1959; ODNB), social campaigner and public servant who converted to Christianity on hearing Henson's sermons at Westminster (see her autobiography Return Passage (1953), 90-1); developed a strong friendship with Henson, continuing until his final years (see Markham papers); shared Henson's opposition to women's suffrage before recanting her former beliefs in 1916; however, discounted the claim of some suffragists that women would transform society, and remained critical of the use of violence for political ends (Return Passage, 98-103); CH, 1917.
William Danks (1845-1916; WWW), canon, Canterbury Cathedral, 1907-1916.
George Moore (1851-1931), Frothingham professor of religion, Harvard, 1904-1928.
Archibald Montgomerie (1880-1945), 16th Earl of Eglinton.
Beatrice Montgomerie [née Dalrymple] (1881-1962).
Charles Lush (1853-1930; WWW), barr.; K.C., 1902.
Michael Hicks-Beach (1877-1916; WWW), Viscount Quenington; oldest son of 1st Earl St Aldwyn; MP (C) Tewkesbury, 1906-16; killed in action.
Edward Marjoribanks, 2nd Baron Tweedmouth (1849-1909; WWW), Conservative politician; first lord of the admiralty, 1905-8; lord president of the council, 1908-9.
Samuel Crockett [né Samuel Crocket] (1859-1914; ODNB), Free Church of Scotland minister and novelist.
William Lancaster [pseudonym, Harry Collingwood] (1843-1922; ODNB), children's writer.
Herbert Miles (1850-1926; WWW), military officer.
Maurice Hewlett (1861-1923; ODNB), novelist and poet.

Neville Lyttelton (1845-1931; ODNB), major- and lieutenant-general during the South African war 1899-1902; commander-in-chief, South Africa, 1902-4; first chief of the general staff, 1904-8; general, 1906; commander-in-chief, Ireland, 1908-12, governor, Chelsea Hospital, 1912-31.
