Bridget Hole (1891-1968), daughter of Samual H. F. Hole and Geraldine Markham; m. (1914) Stephen George Tallents, British civil servant and public relations expert.
Jessie Toler (b. 1891), shorthand typist, 1911; m. (1926) Charles Douglas.
Marguerite Higgs (1892-1983), daughter of Thomas Carpenter Higgs and Ada Woodman; m. (1st) William Earp, (2nd, 1932) Samuel Conroy.
Yvonne Higgs (1894-1987), daughter of Thomas Carpenter Higgs and Ada Woodman; m. Clarence Bourdette.
Grace Huggon (1893-1950), shorthand typist, 1911; m. (1917) Alfred Kiddell.
Ralph Gore (1908-1973), 11th Bt. of Manor Gore.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Ralph Gore (1877-1961), 10th Bt. of Manor Gore; m. (1st, 1905) Elsie Grigg, (2nd, 1943) Beatrice Denison; international yachtsman.
Elsie Gore [née Grigg] (1880-1942).
Lionel Box (1895-1976), piano tuner.
Norman Box (1898-1930), steel worker.
Sydney Duce (1893-1970), book binder, 1911; m. (1914) Ellen Tyler.
Asher Ward (1895-1915), killed in France while serving with the London Irish Rifles.
Cyril Mills (1893-1917).
Reginald Woodyear (1896-1978), served in First World War with the Queen's Own (Royal West Kent) Regiment; MC, 1918.
John Ellis McKibbin (1896-1963), journalist; assistant editor, Amalgamated Press, 1939; m. (1938) Estella Hurst.
Harold Doyle (1894-1984), commerical clerk, 1911.
Edwin Doyle (1895-1952), commerical clerk, 1911.
Frank Armstrong (1895-1970), accountant clerk; m. (1922) Mabel Ethel Walters.
Thomas Sharp (b. 1893), taxicab owner/driver.
Noel Masters (1896-1916), killed in France while serving with the Queen's Westminster Rifles.
Reginald Robins (1896-1938), telephone switchboard attendant, 1911.

Charles Oman (1901-1982), antiquary and curator. Henson's godson; son of Charles William Oman, Chichele professor of military history, Oxford, 1905-46, and Mary Maclagan; m. (1929) Joan Trevelyan; keeper of metalwork, Victoria and Albert Museum, 1945-66.
Mary Gordon [née Clixby] (1857-1937), m. (1st, 1879) Edward Cockayne, (2nd, 1906) George Gordon, 2nd marquess of Aberdeen and Temair.
Henry Cyril Hayward (1894-1917), killed during the First World War while a company sergeant with the 8th Battalion Rifle Brigade.
Leslie Chandler (1897-1964), tobacco buyer; m. (1923) Constance Wilkinson.
Leslie Henry (1896-1916), killed in First World War while serving with the 9th (County of London) Battalion (Queen Victoria's Rifles).

Freeman [Croft-]Wills (d. 1913; WWW), vicar, St. Agatha, Finsbury Park, 1871-1913; founded cadet corps in 1890 while a captain in Volunteer Army, with his own money, and in 1894 secured its affliation with the King's Royal Rifle Corps in 1894, with himself as colonel.
Reginald Copleston (1845-1925; ODNB), bishop of Calcutta and metropolitan of India, 1902-13.
John Walrond (1908-1942), son of William Walrond, MP (C) for Tiverton, 1906-15.
George Lefroy (1854-1919; ODNB), high-church head of the SPG mission, Delhi, 1878-99; bishop of Lahore, 1899-1913; bishop of Calcutta, 1913-9.
Christina 'Mina' Smith, daughter of James Smith and Christina Buchanan; m. (1909) Cunliffe Marsh; Ella's distant cousin.

Olive Smith (1890-1969), daughter of James Smith and Christina Buchanan; m. (1919) Allan Pollok-Morris; Ella's distant cousin; frequently visited the Hensons in Durham before her marriage; Henson considered her like a daughter: Journal, 27 Aug. 1916.
Henry Edye (1867-1947), distant cousin to Ella Henson.
Maud Edye [née Couper] (1874-1934), m. (1896) Henry Edye.
Maximilian 'Max' Kellner (1861-1935), professor of the literature and interpretation of the Old Testament, Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Silas McBee (1853-1924), American architect and teacher; editor, The Churchman, 1896-1912, and The Constructive Quarterly, 1913-23; described as 'one of the most prominent laymen of the Episcopal Church' Lincoln County News, 8 Sep. 1924, 1.
Franklin Spalding (1865-1914), Episcopal bishop of Utah, 1904-14; avowed proponent of the social gospel, commonly referred to as the 'socialist bishop'.
Charles Scadding (1861-1914), Episcopal bishop of Oregon, 1906-14.
Lemuel Wells (1841-1936), Episcopal bishop of Spokane [Washington], 1892-1913.
James Morrison (1844-1934), Episcopal bishop of Duluth [Minnesota], 1897-1922.
Joseph Cheshire (1850-1932), Episcopal bishop of North Carolina, 1893-1932.

John Henry Jowett (1863-1923; ODNB), minister at Carr's Lane Congregrational Church, Birmingham, 1895-1911, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York, 1911-18, and Westminster Congregational Chapel, 1918-21; chairman, Congregational Union, 1909; president, National Free Church Council, 1910-11; called in Sept. 1922 for religious leaders to organise an international peace conference, and then joined with Church of England leaders in a peace campaign.
Francis Jayne (1845-1921; ODNB), bishop of Chester, 1889-1919.
Gladys Lowther (1908-82), daughter of Gerard Lowther, 1st Bt, and Alice Bright; m. (1st, 1933) Charles Fane (2nd, 1942) James Black.
Gerard Lowther (1858-1916; ODNB), British minister in Tangier, 1905-8; ambassador in Contantinople, 1908-1913.
Mary Frances Lowther [née Beresford-Hope] (d. 1944), daughter of Sir Alexander Beresford-Hope and Mildred Gascoyne-Cecil; m. (1886) James Lowther, 1st viscount Ullswater.
Frederick Hillersdon (1854-1944; CCD), rector, St Mary le Bow, London; mayor of Westminster, 1909.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Alfred Cripps (1852-1941; ODNB); barrister, QC 1890; MP (C), Stretford, 1901-6, Wycombe, 1910-14; first baron Parmoor, 1914; member, house of layman, Canterbury Convocation from 1890 (chairman, 1911-19) and Representative Church Council, 1904-20; vicar-general, York province, 1900-14, Canterbury province 1902-24 (resisting legal objections to Henson's appointment as bishop of Hereford); member, archbishops'committee on church and state, 1913-16; chairman, house of laity, Church Assembly, 1920-4; campaigner for the League of Nations; lord president of the council in Labour governments, 1924, 1929-31.

Charles Wood, 2nd viscount Halifax (1839-1934; ODNB), leading anglo-catholic layman. President of the English Church Union, 1869-1919, 1931-4, seeking revival of the catholic nature of the Church of England, defending ritualist clergymen, and promoting reunion with the Roman catholic church; Henson criticised his influence in undermining the 'national tradition of Christianity' in Britain in works from Cui bono: an open letter to Lord Halifax on the present crisis in the Church of England (1899) onwards.
Frederick Bathurst (1827-1910; WWW), archdeacon of Bedford, 1873-1910; former first-class cricketer, Oxford University and Marylebone Cricket Club.
Jacob Primmer (1842-1914), Church of Scotland minister, Townhill, Dunfermline.

Alexander Henderson (c. 1583-1646; ODNB), prominent Church of Scotland minister; a co-author of the Scottish Covenant on 1638; a commissioner in negotiations with Charles I; moderator, general assembly, 1641; member, Westminster Assembly.

William Carstares [Carstairs] (1649-1715; ODNB), a leading figure in the Church of Scotland and advisor to William II (III of England) and subsequent governments in Scotland and England; minister, Greyfriars Kirk, Edinburgh, 1704; moderator, general assembly, 1705.
John Macmillan (1877-1956; WWW), ord. 1904; resident chaplain, archbishop of Canterbury, 1904-15.
Marion Scott [née Rankine] (b. 1854), m. (1894) Archibald Scott; daughter of John Rankine, DD.
David Miller Kay (1866-1930; WWW), professor, Hebrew and Oriental languages, University of St Andrew's, 1902-1930.
Alfred Warr (1860-1916), minister, Rosneath; father of Charles Warr (1892-1969; ODNB), Church of Scotland minister and royal chaplain.
Robert Bruce, master of Burleigh (1880-1914), eldest son of 6th lord Balfour of Burleigh; captain, Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders; killed in action during First World War.

Thomas Martin (1857-1942), Church of Scotland minister, the Barony, Glasgow, 1900-11, then at Peebles; convenor of the home mission committee of the general assembly, from 1909; moderator of the general assembly, 1920.

George Buchanan (1506-82; ODNB), Scottish poet, historian, political theorist, and public servant; moderator of the general assembly of the Church of Scotland, 1567, and tutor of the future James VI and I.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Henry Raeburn (1756-1823; ODNB), leading Scottish portrait painter.

Alfred Tupper-Carey (1866-1943; WWW), head, Christ Church Mission, Poplar, 1898-1901; rector, Lowestoft, 1902-10; canon, York, 1910-17, and Wakefield, 1917-24; SPG secretary, Ripon, Wakefield and Bradford, 1927-30, SPG chaplain, Monte Carlo, 1930; chaplain to the King, 1930-43.
Sidney Alexander (1866-1948; WWW), canon of St Paul's, 1909-48.
Eveline Radcliffe (b. 1908), daughter of George Radcliffe, chapter clerk, Westminster Abbey.
Charles Cruttwell (1847-1911; ODNB), classical scholar, rector of Ewelme, Oxon, 1901-11.
Robert Ottley (1856-1933; WWW), regius professor of moral and pastoral theology and canon of Christ Church, Oxford, 1903-33.
[John] Gordon Craik (1878-1908), captain, 2nd battalion, Seaforth Highlanders; eldest son of Henry Craik; died of tropical fever contracted in Abyssinia [Ethiopia] in 1907.
John Eisdell (1860-1938), chaplain to the vicar of Barking, 1902; vicar of Barking, 1904-16.
Cecil Boutflower (1863-1942; WWW), suffragan bishop of Dorking, 1905-9; bishop of South Tokyo, 1909-21.
Constance Bulwer-Lytton (1869-1923; ODNB), suffragette; daughter of Edward Bulwer-Lytton, first earl of Lytton, and Edith Bulwer-Lytton.
Bliss Perry (1860-1954), literary critic; Harvard lecturer at the University of Paris, 1909-10.

Frederick [F. B.] Meyer (1847-1929; ODNB), baptist minister, Christ Church, Lambeth, 1892-1907, 1915-20, and Regent's Park Chapel, 1909-15; international figure in the Keswick Convention movement; prominent in political nonconformity from 1902; president, Baptist Union, 1906-7; president of the National Free Church Council, 1904-5, 1920-1, and secretary 1910-20; a leader of millenarian Advent Testimony movement from 1917.

William Thomas Stead (1849-1912; ODNB), newspaper editor and spiritualist; as editor of The Pall Mall Gazette, 1883-90, exposed the widespread practice of child prostitution in London, so-called 'white slavery', resulting in the raising of the age of consent in 1889; died on the Titanic.
Zebarney Phillips (1875-42), Episcopal minister, Trinity Church, Chicago, 1903-9.

Phillips Brooks (1835-93), clergyman in the Episcopal church of the USA and liberal Christian, and lyricist of the Christmas hymn, 'O little town of Bethlehem'; influenced Henson's modernism at the beginning of the twentieth century: Henson to Bishop Lawrence, 21 Sept. 1930, Braley, More Letters, 65-6.
Reginald Merton (b. 1889), Oxford undergraduate.
Sarah Lenon (b. 1908), daughter of Joseph Lenon, Cutler, Kensington Place, Westminster.

John Colenso (1814-83; ODNB), bishop of Natal, 1853-83; convicted for heresy and excommunicated in South Africa during 1863, but the verdict was controversially overturned in 1865 by the judicial committee of the privy council.

Angela [Angel] Colenso (1891-1962), daughter of Robert Colenso and Emily Kerr; granddaughter of John Colenso, bishop of Natal; m. (1916) John Thelwall; a frequent visitor and close friend to the Hensons.
Arnold Page (1851-1943; WWW), dean of Peterborough, 1908-28.
William Moore Ede (1849-1935; WWW), dean of Worcester, 1908-34.
Henry Savage (1854-1939; WWW), dean of Lichfield, 1909-39.

Bertram Pollock (1863-1943; ODNB), headmaster, and bishop of Norwich, 1910-42; opposed the Enabling bill; also opposed the revised prayer book as a threat to the comprehensiveness of the national church; derided by Henson in the House of Lords' debate on the prayer book measure, 14 December 1927, for his lofty detachment in the crisis of relations between Church and nation: HL Debs. 5s., LXIX, c. 926.

Joseph Butler Lightfoot (1828-89; ODNB), biblical scholar, and bishop of Durham, 1879-89; advocate of the Revised Version promoted by Henson from his time at Barking, and an original member of the New Testament revision company, 1870-80; Henson praised his church-building in the Durham diocese, but considered as ill-considered his division of the see to create the diocese of Newcastle: Retrospect, II, 79, 91.
Arthur Borrer (b. 1883), solicitor.

Robert Charles (1855-1931; ODNB), Church of England clergyman and biblical scholar; professor of biblical Greek, Trinity Coll., Dublin, 1898-1906; Grinfield lecturer on the Septuagint, Univ. of Oxford, 1905-11; canon of Westminster, 1913-31.

Henry Duke (1855-1939; ODNB), lawyer; MP (U) Plymouth 1900-6, Exeter, 1910-18; chief secretary of Ireland 1916-18; high court judge, 1919-33, chiefly responsible for divorce cases; 1st Baron Merrivale, 1925.
Frederick Pomeroy (1856-1934; ODNB), sculptor; associate and full membership of the royal academy, 1906 and 1917.
Frank Russell (1867-1946; ODNB), barrister; KC, 1908; high court judge, 1919; court of appeal, 1928; 1st baron Russell of Killowen, 1929.
Durward Moffatt (1891-1917), killed in action.
Edward Moffatt (1895-1957).
Joseph Robinson (1840-1929; ODNB), 1st baronet, 1908; diamond mine owner, South Africa; notoriously forced to decline a peerage in 1922, during the 'honours for sale' scandal.
Barten Allen (1862-1940; WWW), vicar, Foleshill and Kemsey, 1894.
Alys Allen [née Beaumont] (d. 1936).

Title: Sir
Narrative: Richard Temple (1826-1902; WWW), 1st baronet, 1876; administrator in India, including governorship of Bombay 1877-80; prolific writer on Indian subjects.
Angus Malcolm (1908-71), 3rd son of Ian Malcolm, 17th laird of Poltallach, and Jeanne Langtry. Diplomatic career from 1933; ambassador to Tunisia, 1956-61.

Basil Bourchier (1881-1934; WWW), first vicar of St Jude-on the Hill, Hampstead garden suburb, 1908-30; while serving in 1914 with the Red Cross in Belgium, arrested by German forces as a spy, but a sentence of death was commuted and he escaped; army chaplain, 1915-16; rector, St Anne's, Soho, 1930-34; a flamboyant preacher, he was satirized as Rev. Cyril Boom Bagshaw in A. S. M. Hutchinson, If winter comes (1921) and as a 'totally preposterous parson' in Evelyn Waugh, A little learning (1964).
Willoughby Allen (1867-1953; WWW), principal of the anglican theological college at Egerton Hall, Manchester, 1908-15.

Joseph Butler (1692-1752; ODNB), moral philosopher and theologian; bishop of Durham, 1750-2; author of The Analogy of Religion (1736), a defence of Christian revelation on grounds of probabilism rather than certainty; encouraged the propagation of religious truth in the same cautious but firm spirit among the clergy in Durham, countering the growing problem of both religious enthusiasm and scepticism during the eighteenth century.
Frances Thesiger [née Guest] (1869-1957), m. (1894) Frederic Thesiger, 3rd lord Chelmsford (1905).
Thomas Bonney (1833-1923; ODNB), geologist; ord. 1858; Yates-Goldsmid professor of geology, University Coll., London, 1877-1901; retired to Cambridge, 1905-23.
Miles Burkitt (1890-1971; WWW), lecturer in archeology, Univ. of Cambridge, 1926-58.
James Balfour Wilson (1865-1941), matriculated, Trinity Coll. Oxford, 1883.
George Kerr (ord. 1897; CCD), curate, St Mary's, Islington, 1903-8.
Samuel Hole (1819-1904; ODNB), dean, Rochester, 1887-1904; moderate high churchman, deeply influenced by the Oxford movement; renowned for his skill as a rose grower.
Hugh Arnold-Forster (1855-1909; ODNB), politician and author; MP (LU), West Belfast, 1892-1906; secretary of state for war, 1903-6.
Elinor Nepean (1874-1963), daughter of St. Vincent Nepean and Anna Julia Blanch; teacher of dance and calisthenics.

Albert Houtin (1867-1926), French Catholic theologian and historian who became disillusioned with religion; attended the fourth international congress of religious liberals in Boston, 1907, organised by Unitarians.
Betty Proby (1899-1978), daughter of Douglas [Hamilton] Proby and Margaret Hely Hutchinson; m. (1920) Henry Lowry-Corry.
[Samuel] John Hole (1892-1962), son of Samuel H. F. Hole and Geraldine Markham; decorated military career; high sheriff, Nottinghamshire, 1961; m. (1953) Mary I. L. Sherbrooke.
Jonathan Brierley (1843-1914; WWW), author and journalist; contributor to Christian World Newspaper; publications include The Eternal Religion (1905).
James Burns (1864-1919; WWW), 3rd Baron Inverclyde (1905), shipowner, financier and sportsman; grandson of the founder of the Cunard Line.
Charlotte Burns [née Nugent-Dunbar] (1865-1951).
John Balfour Browne (1845-1921; WWW), barr.; contested (C) Dumfrieshire, 1906, and East Bradford, 1910.
William Clark Russell (1844-1911; ODNB), novelist; writer of sea stories, including The Wreck of the Grosvenor (1877).
Alexandrina Russell [née Henry] (1845-1926).

James Harrington (1611-77; ODNB), political theorist, best known for his Oceana (1656), a republican tract which outlined the model of a 'Heathenish commonwealth' proposed during the Interregnum; welcomed critics, one of whom was Richard Baxter, who duly published his A Holy Commonwealth (1659).
Mildred Lowther (1890-1973), daughter of James Lowther, 1st viscount Ullswater.
Alfred Cruikshank (1862-1927; WWW), assistant master, Winchester school, 1894-1910; canon and professor of Greek and clasical literature, University of Durham, 1910-27.
Vernon Storr (1869-1940; WWW), rector, Hadbourne Worthy, Hants, 1905-10; rector, St Margaret's, Westminster, 1936-40.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Colin Scott-Moncrieff (1836-1916; WWW), army officer; served in the suppression of the Indian Mutiny; member, Athenaeum.
Mary Scott-Moncrieff [née Albright] (1851-1936).
Alexander Lawrence (1874-1939; WWW), solicitor, and Treasury civil servant; 4th baronet (1907).
Anne Lawrence [née Wynne] (1873-1950).
William Willcocks (1852-1932; ODNB), civil engineer; director of irrigation, Egypt, 1883-97; architect of the Aswan Dam, 1898; KCMG, 1902.
Francis Channing (1841-1926; WWW), American-born; sometime fellow in philosophy, Exeter Coll., Oxford; MP (L) East Northamptonshire, 1885-1910; 1st Baron Channing of Wellingborough, 1912.

Hilaire Belloc (1870-1953; ODNB), poet, writer, and Roman catholic; MP (L) South Salford, 1906-10; bitter critic of the ministers caught up in the Marconi scandal in 1913, and of parliamentary democracy more widely; contributed a weekly article to Land and Water, a journal with a wide circulation devoted exclusively to the First World War.
Sydney Buxton (1853-1934; ODNB), MP (L), Poplar 1886-1914, postmaster-general 1905-10; president, board of trade, 1910-14; governor-general, South Africa, 1914-20; viscount Buxton, 1914; earl, 1920.
Harry Darwin Burton (1858-43), diocesan missioner, St Alban's, 1892-1910.

George Kitchin (1827-1912; ODNB), as non-affiliated teacher for various Oxford colleges, established in 1868 the scheme of non-collegiate membership of the University of Oxford, from which Henson later benefitted; dean of Durham, 1894-1912; supported the Boers from the Cathedral pulpit during the South African War; the last dean of Durham to be ex-officio warden of the University of Durham, a change he helped to effect in 1908.
Millicent Foster (1875-1961), daughter of Sir Walter Foster, MP; m. William Poole (1871-1946), schoolmaster, modern languages, Royal Naval College, Isle of Wight.
Charles Geake (1867-1919; WWW), member of the editorial staff, Westminster Gazette, 1896-1919.
Jessie Geake [née Hudson] (b. 1870).

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Puleston (1830-1908; WWW), journalist, stockbroker, and MP (C) Devonport, 1874-92; kt, 1887.
Joseph Byrne (1874-1942; WWW), army officer, Royal Inniskilling Fusilliers, 1893; served in the South African War; wounded at Ladysmith; governor and commander-in-chief, Kenya, 1931-7; KBE, 1918.
Marjorie Byrne [née Joseph] (d. 1960).
William Leonard (1848-1930), Episcopal bishop of Ohio, 1889-1930.
Winifred Coombe Tennant [née Pearce-Serocold] (1874-1956; ODNB), suffragist, spiritualist medium, and public servant.
Daphne Coombe Tennant (1907-8).
(possibly) Walter Smith (1848-1922; WWW), secretary, Winchester Diocesan Conference, 1903-20.
Arthur Day (1867-1942), Jesuit priest, St Ignatius, Preston, Lancashire.

Title: Sir
Narrative: John Day (1828-1908; ODNB), judge and Roman Catholic; member of the Parnell Commission.
Robert Sewell (1860-1928), minister, Great George Street, Liverpool.
Thomas Wilkinson (ord. 1908; CCD), curate, St Bede's, Toxteth, 1908.
William Cogswell (1845-1917); rector of Wallasey from 1895.

Thomas Alexander Lacey (1853-1931; WWW), council member, English Church Union, 1891-1931; chaplain and warden, London Diocesan Penitentiary, Highgate, 1903-19; member of editorial committee, English Hymnal (1906).
Bernard Rellen (1891-1949), local parishioner.

John Williams (1582-1650), born and died in North Wales; dean of Westminster, 1620-44, and a benefactor of the Abbey and School; lord keeper, 1621-5; bishop of Lincoln, 1621-41, as an oppnent of Laud, imprisoned, 1636-40; archbishop of York, 1641-6.

Walter Phillimore (1845-1929; ODNB), 2nd bt. 1885; fellow, All Souls Coll., Oxford; as barrister and counsel, defended anglo-catholic clergymen in 'ritualist' cases brought by evangelicals at the turn of the nineteenth century; judge, Queen's bench, 1897; lord of appeal, 1913; 1st baron Phillimore, 1918; active member of the English Church Union, president in 1919 and vice-president thereafter; longstanding member of house of laity, Canterbury convocation, and house of layman, Church Assembly; member, parliamentary ecclesiastical committee 1920; prominent supporter of prayer book revision.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Samuel Evans (1859-1918; ODNB), lawyer, QC, 1901; MP (L) Mid-Glamorgan, 1890-1910; a free church critic of the Church of England; attorney-general, 1908-10; kt, 1908; high court judge, 1910.
[Granville] George Greenwood (1850-1928; WWW), writer; MP (L) Peterborough, 1906-18; prominent contributor to the debate concerning Shakespeare's authorship; Kt, 1916.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Fleetwood Edwards (1842-1910), military officer and Keeper of the Privy Purse to Queen Victoria, 1895-1901, and one of her executors; GCVO, 1901.
Bernard Forbes (1874-1948; WWW), 8th Earl Granard; military officer, courtier, and Liberal politician.
Mary Percival [née Symonds] (1851-1926).

Christian Craster [née Caröe] (1894-1973), daughter of Henson's friend the architect W.D. Caröe, whose three children Henson befriended; m. George Craster, a colonel in the Indian cavalry, in Bengal, 1923.
Eleanor Marsden (1842-1932), widowed sister-in-law of Thomas Marsden.
Arthur Walpole (b. 1859), cab proprietor, Lambeth.
Ann Walpole [née Rumball] (b. 1855).
Henry Thornton (1842-1926), JP and partner in the bank of Samuel Smith and Company; son of Rev. Spencer Thornton (1813-50) and Caroline Adelaide Du Pré.
Henry Russell (1842-1922), rector, Wollaton, Nottingham, 1876-1922.
Charles Russell (1807-94), 6th son of John, 6th duke of Bedford, by his second wife, Georgina [née Gordon]; sergeant-at-arms, house of commons, 1848-75.

John Russell (1792-1878; ODNB), 1st Earl Russell (1861), Liberal statesman and prime minister, 1846-52, 1865-66; 3rd son of John, 6th duke of Bedford, by his first wife, Georgiana Elizabeth [née Byng].

Herbert Wild (1865-1940; WWW), vicar, St John the Evangelist, Carrington, Nottingham, 1905-1909; vicar, St Giles', Oxford, 1909-13; archdeacon of Nottingham and rector of Southwell, 1913-15; bishop of Newcastle, 1915-27.
Helen Wild [née Severn] (1873-1942).
Walter Severn (1830-1904; ODNB), watercolour painter; son of Joseph Severn (1793-1879; ODNB), painter and friend of John Keats.
Claude Thornton (1878-1934; WWW), vicar, Greasly, Notts., 1907-12.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Charles Seely (1859-1926; WWW), 2nd bt (1896), MP (LU) Lincoln, 1895-1906, (L) Mansfield, 1916-18; Lt-col, 5th volunteers, Isle of Wight, 1900-8; address, Gatcombe House, Isle of Wight; Sherwood Lodge, Arnold, Notts.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Joseph Bright (1849-1918; WWW), alderman, City of Nottingham; kt, 1906.
Mary Hoskyns [née Benson] (1853-1939).
Edwin Sandys (c. 1519-1588; ODNB), bishop of Worcester, 1559-70, and London 1570-76; archbishop of York, 1576-88.

Edward Trollope (1817-93), bishop suffragan of Nottingham, 1877-93; helped to establish the new see of Southwell, 1884, and to restore the Great Hall next to Southwell Minster as the bishop's palace; however, the Church Commissioners declined to adopt and fund the palace.
Robert Sanderson (1587-1663; ODNB), bishop of Lincoln, 1660-63.
Charles Pierrepont (1854-1926; WWW), Viscount Newark; MP (C) Nottinghamshire, 1885-95, 1898-1900; landowner and general in the volunteer forces; 4th Earl Manvers (1900).
Henry Thornton (1760-1815; ODNB), banker and political economist, and a founder of the Clapham Sect.

Katherine Thornton [née Grenfell] (1843-1906), daughter of Catherine Anne Du Pré and Pascoe St Lyer Grenfell (1798-1879; ODNB), industrialist and son of Pascoe Grenfell (b. 1761, d. 1838), MP with close links to Wilberforce and the Clapham Sect, and founder of the family firm of copper smelting; m. (1871) Henry Thornton, her first cousin.
Francis Grenfell (1841-1925; ODNB), army officer; commander-in-chief, Ireland, 1904-8; 1st baron Grenfell of Kilvey, Co. Glamorgan, 1902.
Isabel Thornton [née Smith] (1866-1942), descendant of Abel Smith (1788-1859; ODNB), banker and politician; m. (1908) Henry Thornton.
Horatia Erskine [née Seymour] (1842-1922), daughter of the 5th Marquess of Hereford.
Godfrey Thornton (1881-1918), lieutenant-colonel, Royal Field Artillery; served in India for ten years; died of wounds sustained in battle in the First World war.
Gertrude Seely [née Thornton] (1882-1967).
John Thornton (1884-1969), ord. 1909; curate, St Andrew's, Bishop Auckland, 1908-12.
Henry Thornton (1873-1934), estate agent, Glamorgan (1911 census).
Pascoe Thornton (1877-1917), merchant navy seaman; served as an interpreter in the Chinese Labour Corps, First World War; died in hospital in Tientsin.
Frank Seely (1864-1928), lt. col., South Notts Hussars; proprietor of family colliery, Babbington; 2nd son of Sir Charles Seely, 1st bt.

John Seely (1868-1947; ODNB), MP (C) Isle of Wight, 1900-4 and (L) 1904-6; (L) Abercromby, Liverpool, 1906-10; Ilkeston, 1910-22; under-secretary, colonies, 1908-10, and war, 1911; secretary of war, 1912-14, resigning in consequence of the Curragh incident; army service and major-general during the First World War; junior minister, 1918; 1st Baron Mottistone, 1933.
Alma 'Cissy' Rawle (1885-1957), daughter of Henson's cousin, Arthur Rawle, and Alma Strong; m. (1911) Henry Patteson Strong.
Arthur Meredyth Burke (1872-1920), major, Royal Artillery, FSA; editor, Memorials of St Margaret's, Westminster: the parish registers, 1539-1660 (1914), to which Henson contributed a preface.
Dorothy Tait (1894-1949), daughter of Edward Tait and Frances Willett; m. (1914) Hugh Russell-Smith.
Henry Troutbeck (1866-1923), physician and surgeon; son of Elizabeth Forbes Duckworth and John Troutbeck (1832-99), minor canon, Westminster Abbey; m. (1900) Ellen Sarah Strickland.
Ellen Troutbeck [née Strickland] (1862-1936), m. (1900) Henry Troutbeck.
Wilfred Troutbeck (1902-1985), electrical engineer; son of Henry and Ellen Troutbeck.
Harriet Troutbeck [née Monro] (1862-1935), m. (1889) John Troutbeck.

Title: Sir
Narrative: Charles Oman (1860-1946; ODNB), historian. Fellow, All Souls', Oxford, 1883-1946; chichele professor of military history, Oxford, 1905-46; close friend to Henson, who was godfather to his son Charles (b. 1901).
Mary Oman [née Maclagan] (1866-1950), daughter of Patricia Gilmour and Robert Maclagan, Scottish military general and engineer; m. (1892) Charles Oman.
Mary Emmott [née Lees], m. (1887) Alfred Emmott.

Herbert Nicholson (1896-1972), Henson's godson; son of Thomas Nicholson and Elizabeth Snell; m. (1924) Agnes Fensom; assistant ironmonger, 1911; soap salesman, 1939; while a young man, Henson pledged to help support his apprenticeship.

John Scott (1879-1917), son of Edgeworth Hill and John Scott, an English judge who worked primarily in India and Egypt; m. (1916) Madeleine Ethel Worsley; Lt Col, killed in France while serving with the Somerset Light Infantry.
Wilmot Parker Smith (1885-1915), son of James Parker Smith and Mary Louisa Hamilton; military career, died of wounds, Gallipoli.
